Project: Supporting policy makers and sports practitioners drive equality and tackle gender-based violence in and through sport
Description: In the framework of Fit for Life implementation, the Sport Section will support policy makers and sports practitioners design and deliver inclusive sport policies and programmes that empower girls and women from all backgrounds, and tackle gender-based violence. The Sport Section will launch the Fit for Life Sport and Gender Equality Game Plan, a practical toolkit designed to support decisionmakers implement gender equality commitments and measure both progress in this regard, as well as the return on investments. As part of this work, the Sport Section will mobilize Member States and members of the Fit for Life Global Alliance to promote and adopt the recommendations of the UNESCO-UN Women ‘Handbook on Tackling Violence Against Women and Girls in Sport’, through advocacy campaigns, events, knowledge exchange and coalition-building. Implementation of both the Game Plan and the Handbook will be supported through pilot projects in countries and cities in a later phase, with a special focus on impact measurement and participatory policy-making.
Outcome EN: Outcome 7 - Promote inclusion and combat discrimination, hate speech and stereotypes
Output EN: 7.SHS3 - Member States capacities are strengthened to scale up their policy, institutional and legislative actions towards gender equality, to eliminate gender-based violence and discrimination, gender biases and stereotypes, including in the digital worl

Project: Enhancing the capacities to promote and protect linguistic diversity and multilingualism in cyberspace.
Description: The countries in the Jakarta cluster contains a rich linguistic diversity. In Indonesia, around 700 languages are spoken across its 17500 islands, in Malaysia around 130 languages are spoken, in the Philippines around 120 languages are spoken, whereas in Timor-Leste about twelve languages are spoken in the island state. Nevertheless, as in other parts of the world, many of these indigenous languages are under threat and are in danger of being forgotten. Many of these languages are also not available natively on the Internet, making it difficult to attract younger generations to use and interact digitally in their indigenous languages.
Outcome EN: Outcome 5 - Enhance the protection and promotion of the diversity of heritage and cultural expressions
Output EN: 5.CI1 - Member States have enhanced capacities to promote and protect linguistic diversity and multilingualism, including in the framework of the International Decade of Indigenous Languages 2022-2032

Project: Strengthening the capacity and raising awareness on freedom of expression, safety of women and men journalists and access to information online and offline
Description: The media in the region faces different challenges and obstacles on the road to becoming a free, safe, independent, and pluralistic media environment. These includes political instability, vague or inconsistent media laws, lack of diversity of media that is partially linked to media viability issues, as well as sporadic attacks, imprisonments, and even death of journalists. There are also classic media development challenges including lack of capacity building, technology, and funding.
Outcome EN: Outcome 6 - Promote freedom of expression and the right to information
Output EN: 6.CI2 - Member States have strengthened capacities and raised awareness to enhance norms and policies related to freedom of expression, press freedom, safety of journalists, including women journalists, and the right to access information, online and offl

Project: Development of Media
Description: Information is a public good, and independent media nourishes democracy precisely by keeping citizens informed, raising their knowledge about public affairs, brokering dialogue and helping them understand each other. Impartially informed and knowledgeable citizens can actively participate in democracy and make informed decisions. Media pluralism provides choice to the public. It is enabled by having a mix of public, private and community media, and offering a wide range of platforms (print, radio, TV and online) to avoid media concentration, which could restrict diversity of opinions and viewpoints in circulation. In this framework, MDE helps Member States ensure a diverse media landscape.
Outcome EN: Outcome 6 - Promote freedom of expression and the right to information
Output EN: 6.CI3 - Member States and media institutions enabled to strengthen media development and media pluralism, including through the International Programme for the Development of Communication (IPDC)

Project: Sustainable Hydrosystems: Integrating Ecohydrology and Local Ecological Knowledge (LEK) into Inclusive Water Resource Management
Description: Recognizing the significance of local ecological knowledge (LEK), as demonstrated by traditional practices such as Bali's Subak system, becomes imperative in fostering sustainable integrated water resource management (IWRM), underscores the importance of considering social, environmental, and economic factors. In this context, Ecohydrology, combining hydrological and biological processes, is crucial for ensuring water security and biodiversity in Indonesia. To achieve this, a proposed project aims to enhance knowledge co-production between Ecohydrology and LEK, aiming to improve integrated water resource management. The project aims to develop a framework strategy and improve Ecohydrology adoption, emphasizing stakeholder engagement through workshops and seminars.
Outcome EN: Enabling Outcome 10 - Reinforced partnerships, outreach and advocacy in support of UNESCO’s action

Project: Promoting Local Natural Dyes to Young Generations to Achieve the Sustainable Development Goals
Description: The revival of natural dyes in Indonesia aligns with the national industrial agenda, focusing on eco-friendly dye industries for textiles. Since 2019, UGM researchers under INDI have driven community-oriented initiatives, recognized by UNESCO. INDI's holistic approach targets revitalizing the natural dye industry and meeting global sustainability goals. To advance as a UNESCO Chair, INDI UGM proposes "Promoting Local Natural Dyes to Young Generations to Achieve the Sustainable Development Goals," engaging undergraduate and high-school students with a vulnerable society of craftswomen. The program aims to raise awareness, empower youth, and foster collaboration within the natural dye community through education, research, and community empowerment by 3 main activities of 8 workshops/conference/meetings, 2 trainings, and 2 publications.

Project: Awareness-raising and capacity building on the Deer stone monuments of Mongolia
Description: The project aims to enhance the understanding and appreciation of the Deer Stone culture, which holds significant historical and cultural significance in Mongolia. Following its recent recognition on the UNESCO World Heritage List, the project is designed to achieve educational and cultural objectives through a range of activities such as research conferences, workshops, and grant programs. Through the dissemination of knowledge via publications and initiatives, the project seeks to amplify the OUV of Deer Stone sites, thereby encouraging increased social involvement in preserving cultural heritage both nationally and locally.

Project: Digitizing and Enhancing Accessibility of the National Atlas of Mongolia (E-NAM)
Description: The project aims to create an electronic version of the National Atlas of Mongolia or E-NAM, which consists of thematic geographical images, incorporating research findings from disciplines such as history, archaeology, paleontology, biology, geology, physics, geophysics, ecology, geography, and cartography, by recreating the thematic geographical images in English and placing them on an online platform in two languages, Mongolia and English. This comprehensive and open-access atlas will provide and enhance the science-based knowledge and understanding of Mongolia to the general public and interdisciplinary researchers of all ages, genders, and ethnicities, which aligns with strategic orientations of UNESCO for period 2024-2025.

Project: Empowering women in STEM
Description:
“Empowering women in STEM” is a program aimed at eliminating gender inequality in STEM-related fields by enhancing their skills and advancing social participation of young women pursuing STEM-related fields. Zorig Foundation has a proven track record of successfully implementing such programs, with a total of 40 graduates as of 2024.

Project: Mongolia: Enhancing Educational Resilience in Response to Dzud Disaster.
Description: The emergency project addresses immediate educational challenges caused by dzud disaster while fortifying readiness for future emergencies. Amidst the current crisis, it provides essential support to mitigate disruptions and enhance educational resilience. By supplying connectivity resources, training, and guidelines, the project ensures continuity of education. Simultaneously, it lays the groundwork for future emergencies, equipping communities with the knowledge and resources needed to respond effectively. Through this dual approach, the project aims to safeguard education during crises while fostering long-term resilience to similar emergencies.

Project: Developing a comprehensive Science, Technology and Innovation Strategy in Lao PDR (2026-2040) through public private consultation and partnerships
Description: As Lao PDR aims to graduate from the LDC status by 2026, there is a pressing need for an official national science, technology and innovation (STI) strategy and action plan that is aligned to the national development priorities. The government needs to work on the current challenge of technological and globalization changes, as well as social transformation through a comprehensive STI strategy, according to the standards of UNESCO Recommendation on Science and Scientific Researchers (2017). The Strategy will integrate and articulate the national and social and human sciences in a unified way, in support of the implementation of the 10th National Socioeconomic Development Plan 2026-2023. This project will build on the ongoing collaboration (since 2023) between the Ministry and the UNESCO Regional Office (based in Bangkok) by assisting the government in broadening the national consultations with the private sector (including SME) in order to enact an comprehensive and participatory approach while drafting the STI policy.
Outcome EN: Enabling Outcome 10 - Reinforced partnerships, outreach and advocacy in support of UNESCO’s action

Project: Sustainable Future in Youth Hands: Bridging ESD Action and Youth Leadership Among ASPnet Schools
Description: This project addresses the interconnected global challenges of sustainability through Education for Sustainable Development (ESD). It empowers youth in Lao PDR, particularly those in ASPnet schools, by providing them with the knowledge, skills, and values necessary to become active advocates for a sustainable future in their communities. The project focuses on enhancing the capacity of ASPnet schools to integrate ESD, empowering students, and fostering collaboration among educators, students, and local stakeholders. By equipping young people with the necessary tools, this project aims to create a generation of changemakers who will contribute to achieving national and global sustainable development goals.

One of culture’s manifestations is living heritage or intangible cultural heritage (ICH), including music and dances, festivals and rituals, making handicrafts and agricultural knowledge. Project: Awareness raising and capacity building for fight against illicit trafficking of cultural property
Description:
Setting fight against illicit import, export and transfer of ownership of cultural property, as one of the priority in the field of culture, Ministry of Culture of the Republic of Serbia, will focus on awareness raising and capacity building of police and customs officers in training with the aim of having them prepared to recognized potential crimes against cultural property and use available tools. The project Awareness raising and capacity building for fight against illicit trafficking of  cultural property 
 is a continuation of successfully implemented activities within the project Capacity building for fighting illicit import, export and transfer of ownership of cultural property on local level  (Participation Programme  2021-2022). Тhis project included an online workshop and two workshops in the City of Knjaževac ( the Native Museum in Knjaževac)  and in the City of Sremska Mitrovica (the City Museum of Srem).   
The both workshops included a visit to archaeological sites (Timakum Minus archaeological site – Knjaževac and  Sirmium Imperial Palace – Sremska Mitrovica)  and constructive on-the-spot discussion. The expected results of the project have been entirely fulfilled. Through the implementation of three workshops, all relevant participants in the process of protection of cultural heritage and the fight against illicit trade in cultural property, have undergone a type of training and a comprehensive approach within this process, which includes the readiness of local structures and the establishment of a single procedure concerning activities undertaken in case of illicit import, export and trade, as well as in case of illicit excavation. Workshop participants were introduced to the applicable legislative framework of the Republic of Serbia and the UNESCO conventions concerning this matter, primarily the Convention for the Protection of Cultural Property in the Event of Armed Conflict (The Hague, 1954), the Convention on the Means of Prohibiting and Preventing the Illicit Import, Export and Transfer of Ownership of Cultural Property (Paris, 1970), and Convention Concerning the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage (Paris, 1972). The implementation of the project and the participation of all relevant actors at the national and local level contributed to the mapping of new problems in the fight against illicit trade in cultural property and illegal excavations of archaeological sites, but also to establishing previously identified problems on which all departments, each within its competence, work continuously.
Outcome EN: Enabling Outcome 10 - Reinforced partnerships, outreach and advocacy in support of UNESCO’s action

Project: Pushing the Boundaries: Cultivating Inclusion in Ukrainian UNESCO Associated Schools
Description: The project strives to address the post-war challenges in Ukraine by fostering inclusivity in education through UNESCO Associated Schools. It aligns with international frameworks, emphasizing inclusive education principles. The initiative empowers teachers with inclusive teaching strategies, addressing biases and unique needs of war-affected students. Student training programs promote inclusivity, resilience, and collaboration. Expected results include enhanced teaching competencies, a cultivated inclusive school culture, empowered student advocates, improved well-being, and measurable academic progress. Implemented in UNESCO schools, the project aims to create a sustainable impact, reinforcing UNESCO’s commitment to positive educational change and supporting post-war recovery in Ukraine.

Project: SPECIAL AND INCLUSIVE EDUCATION PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT FOR TEACHERS
Description: This proposed  project aims to transform teacher  education through the implementation of a comprehensive teacher capacity development program aimed at supporting teachers to identify students with learning disabilities and provide the needed support that will help them excel. The project leverages a participatory approaches to teacher professional development. The project will bring together expertise of ADO and our  partners  in Ghana Education Service to train 500 Ghanaian primary and junior high school teachers  and those in teacher training colleges through an innovative online course. The course is designed to run for two months with bi-weekly check-ins with lead trainers to  address the diverse needs of students, particularly those with learning disabilities like dyslexia and dyscalculia.

Project: Introducing Living Heritage and Cultural Expressions in Gambian Schools to Safeguard the National Inventoried List of Intangible Cultural Heritage
Description:
The Gambia’s culture sector is characterized by diversity and heterogeneity. As Gambia subscribes to most of the UNESCO cultural conventions, this calls for strengthening the safeguarding of both the tangible and intangible aspects of its cultural heritage, including the arts, for a more peaceful and inclusive society. It is pertinent to rally around the country’s cultural diversity as a source of inspiration to galvanize its people for better understanding and mutual respect of each other’s values and traditions. 

Upon ratifying the UNESCO 2003 Convention on the Safeguarding of the Intangible Cultural Heritage (ICH), the Government of The Gambia committed to safeguarding ICH elements in its territory. This includes inventorying ICH, raising public awareness about the importance of safeguarding ICH and its contribution to sustainable development, and supporting communities in their efforts to safeguard ICH. To this end, the country has recently inventoried 30 ICH elements in its national list of endangered living heritages. This new initiative augurs very well with the vision of the country to enliven these intangible cultural elements with the younger generations of The Gambia. Some of these elements have both gender and sustainable development connotations and it would be a good drive to engage children and their teacher coordinators in ASPnet and Clubs for UNESCO schools to understand and adapt them into their lives in order to foster the appreciation of Gambian culture and values.
Outcome EN: Enabling Outcome 10 - Reinforced partnerships, outreach and advocacy in support of UNESCO’s action

Project: Effects of Electronic and medical waste on the Environment and Human Health: Engaging Schools and Communities to advocate for a more resilient ecosystem management
Description:
As we sail through the digital age, a new frontier has emerged in the realm of environmental protection—the online sphere. This vast interconnected landscape has become an essential catalyst in propelling discussions about various environmental issues, and medical waste management sits at the forefront of these conversations. According to statistics, of the total waste generated by health-care activities, 15% is considered hazardous material that may be infectious, toxic, or radioactive. Given the tremendous environmental repercussions associated with mishandling medical waste, it is imperative to address this issue head-on. In this project write-up, we will explore the intricate dynamics of medical waste, its environmental impact, the role of technology, existing challenges, and inspirational initiatives that provide a beacon of hope.
Medical waste is a huge environmental issue and according to records, every year, an estimated 16 billion injections are administered worldwide, but not all of the needles and syringes are properly disposed of afterward. Furthermore, the advent of the Covid pandemic has exacerbated the impact of medical waste. As demand for Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) – including gloves, masks, and gowns – grew worldwide in response to the Covid-19 outbreak in the last two years, medical waste disposal rates skyrocketed.

According to the World Health Organization (WHO), there are 8 types of medical waste: (Infectious waste, Pathological waste, Sharps waste, Chemical waste, Pharmaceutical waste, Cytotoxic waste, Radioactive waste, Non-hazardous or general waste).

The Covid-19 pandemic was not just a public health crisis, but an environmental crisis, too. An estimated 8 million metric tons of plastics already enter the ocean on an annual basis. According to a report by the World Health Organization, the medical waste accumulated during the pandemic increased plastic pollution in the oceans by 10 times.


On the other hand electrical and electronic devices generating e-waste are from IT and telecommunication equipment and consumer electrical/electronic products such as refrigerators, washing machines, computers and its accessories, brails, mobile phones and chargers, remotes, compact discs, headphones, batteries, LCD/Plasma TVs, i-pods, air conditioners, dryers, fridge, VCRs, stereos, copiers, fax machines, video games, presenters, music system and other household appliances etc. many of which contain toxic materials. It is estimated that about 50 million tonnes of e-waste is generated every year all over the world.

Consequently, as the Gambia is part of the global community, the management of hazardous electric/electronic and medical waste forms part of the major challenges the country is grappling with like many developing countries. Medical and e-waste are major problems posing very significant health and environmental hazards.

Project: DEVELOPING EFFECTIVE CONTENT MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES AND ENHANCING STAFF CAPACITIES FOR OPTIMAL UTILIZATION OF MOES VIRTUAL INFORMATION CENTRE
Description:
The Ministry of Education and Sports (MoES) in Uganda has made significant strides in enhancing access to a diverse array of educational resources by establishing a digital/Virtual Information Centre (VIC) with support from UNESCO during the last Biennium, serving as a vital platform for disseminating crucial educational resources and information materials to both internal stakeholders within the MoES and the broader public.
Despite the extensive resources available within the centre, their utilization remains significantly below potential. This underutilization is primarily due to the absence of effective content management strategies and insufficient staff capacities among others.
Building upon this foundation, this project aims to develop comprehensive content management strategies, enhance staff capacities and promote the VIC among other stakeholders to maximize the utilization of the MoES Virtual Information Centre (VIC) in Uganda.

Project: Capacity building and awareness creation of law enforcement officers on safety of Journalists, freedom of expression and the right to information in Uganda
Description:
Media Workers and Law enforcement agencies are often faced with many challenges to balance the rights to freedom of expression with the imperative to maintain impartiality and public order management. During turbulent times, law enforcement agencies have had to manage public safety issues around elections, natural disasters and public health emergencies, and facilitate respect for freedom of expression and the right to peaceful assembly. Political, social and economic circumstances have increasingly encouraged unrest among the public, placing officers in often difficult situations.
Against this backdrop, journalists and their freedom are increasingly threathened. A total of 1,088 journalsist have been killed for their work or while on job within the last 12 years. In the first half of 2022 alone, 45 media professionals have been killed. In response, government and law enforcement agencies have had to examine their ways of dealing with public order issues, working with journalists and communicating effectively with the public.
Despite the fact that media in Uganda has tremendously expanded and that Uganda’s 1995 constitution, the Press and Journalist Act, 1995 and other existing laws guarantee press freedom, so little has been done to promote media rights, safety and improvement of the working climate and conditions . The threats to free expression and access to information still remain in place. Together with the growing influence of business interests on the media, the threats continue to pose major challenges to the campaign for open dialogue, democratic rights and good governance in Uganda.  Concerns of this nature continue to keep human rights defenders in the country on their toes in search for ways to protect and promote open spaces where divergent ideas can flourish to foster democracy.
The Ugandan constitution and other existing laws guarantee press freedom, but the state actors usually ignores them at will. To compound the problem, the rate of impunity for crimes against journalists, media workers and social media producers remains high. Those involved in harassing media are never investigated and prosecuted. It is upon this background that we need as a country to promote press freedom at all level so that the gains realized is not washed away by the State actors.

Project: PROMOTION OF ENVIRONMENTAL AND CLIMATE CHANGE EDUCATION IN THE PRIMARY TEACHERS TRAINING CURRICULUM
Description:
The project has been designed to promote integration of environmental education including climate change into the Primary Teachers Training Curriculum in Uganda.  
The approach to implementation of the project will include reviewing the existing Primary Teachers training curriculum for integration of environmental education. The review process will be participatory involving key actors in Teacher Education training and development. Workshops will be organized to assess teaching content including curriculum guides, leaners’ textbooks, examination papers and related materials among others. The review process will also help in determining tentative themes and some of the key actors to be engaged in subsequent stages.  This will be followed by participatory consultations where both physical and virtual media will be utilized and validation of the first report will be undertaken. The consultations and data collection are expected to target pre- service teachers’ learners in Primary Schools, District Education Officers, District Inspectors of Schools, Area Centre Coordinating Tutors, community members and environmental experts, educators including in service teachers, school administrators, curriculum specialists, examiners, education policy makers and related institutions among others. A series of engagements will be organized for data and information generation, validation, reporting and dissemination. The next stage will involve development of the Tutors guide or manual. The Tutors manual or resource book will be a practical support material for Tutors and preservice teachers in Primary Teacher Training Institutions. It will provide basic information on environmental education and Climate Change Mitigation actions in Primary Teachers Training Institutions A training of master trainers will be conducted who in turn will train selected tutors at regional levels to strengthen the capacity of Teacher Educators to promote A training of master trainers will be conducted who in turn will train selected tutors at regional levels to strengthen the capacity of Teacher educators to manage and promote environmental education and Climate Change Mitigation actions in Primary Teachers Training Institutions

Project: Projet d’éducation à la gestion durable des ressources en eau dans les établissements scolaires du Burkina Faso
Description:
Le projet d’éducation à la gestion durable des ressources dans les établissements scolaires du Burkina Faso véhicule des messages forts à travers ce constat : 

  L’eau est une grande préoccupation dans les pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest et sa bonne gestion est un devoir pour les gouvernants qui ont une obligation de moyens et pour chaque citoyen qui se doit d’adopter les bons comportements pour assurer la pérennité de cette ressource en eau. Bien plus que la vulnérabilité des pays de la zone face à une pluviométrie largement déficitaire et irrégulière, la prise de conscience des enjeux liés à l’eau a progressivement convergé vers un consensus pour une approche innovatrice de gestion des ressources en eau. La Gestion Intégrée des Ressources en Eau (GIRE) est ainsi apparue comme une des approches pour atteindre la bonne gouvernance de l’eau.

Project: « Apprendre pour vivre ensemble :  Contribution du réseau des écoles associées de l’UNESCO du BURKINA FASO »
Description:
Les messages forts à travers le projet intitulé : « Apprendre pour vivre ensemble : Contribution du réseau des écoles associées de l’UNESCO du BURKINA FASO » sont que :
Le Burkina Faso, à l’instar des autres pays de la région du Sahel traverse une crise sécuritaire difficile marquée par des attaques terroristes qui affectent beaucoup le système éducatif. Selon le rapport de l’Éducation en Situation d’Urgence du Ministère de l’Éducation nationale et de l’Alphabétisation et de la Promotion des Langues nationale  du 31 décembre 2023, 5330 écoles sont fermées avec 820 865 élèves déplacés internes  et 23955 enseignants soit 20% de l’ensemble des structures éducatives.  Au nombre des écoles fermées figurent les écoles associées à l’UNESCO. Il convient de relever qu’il existe au Burkina Faso, plus de deux cent (200) écoles associées à l’UNESCO mais la plupart sont fermées à cause de la situation sécuritaire. Cette situation préjudiciable à une éducation de qualité compromet les actions de l’UNESCO.

Project: Séminaire – Atelier de contribution à une stratégie nationale de promotion et développement du Handisport au Gabon
Description:
Le sport de masse est un puissant instrument pour promouvoir l’inclusion et rassembler les gens. Lorsqu’il est ciblé et fondé sur des valeurs et une éducation physique de qualité, il peut avoir un impact positif sur la vie des personnes, en particulier celles se trouvant dans des situations vulnérables, telles que les personnes en situation de handicap. 
Créée en 1976, la Conférence Internationale des Ministres et Hauts Fonctionnaires responsables de l'Education Physique et du Sport (MINEPS) est un forum qui facilite l’échange intellectuel et technique en matière d’éducation physique et de sport. Au terme de sa Septième (7e) Conférence internationale (MINEPS VII), organisée à Bakou (République d'Azerbaïdjan) du 26 au 29 juin 2023, les Etats membres ont encore donné au sport la place qui lui revient dans l'agenda international par l’adoption de l’Alliance Fit4Life « en forme pour la vie ».
« En forme pour la vie » est programme basé sur le sport et conçu pour soutenir et améliorer  l’élaboration de politiques inclusives et intégrés de la pratique du sport comme facteur d’épanouissement des populations et de transformation. 
Au Gabon, du fait de sa nature, le Comité Intergouvernemental pour l’Education Physique et le Sport (CIGEPS) de la Commission Nationale Gabonaise pour l’UNESCO, a le potentiel pour engager le gouvernement gabonais dans un effort national coordonné pour optimiser les bénéfices socio-économiques tangibles des programmes de sport et d’éducation physique, et de défendre des investissements intelligents dans le sport pour un développement durable dans le cadre global du Programme à l’horizon 2030.
Outcome EN: Enabling Outcome 10 - Reinforced partnerships, outreach and advocacy in support of UNESCO’s action

Project: Atelier de sensibilisation et d’Appui à l’Elaboration d’une Stratégie nationale de l’Intelligence Artificielle (IA) au Gabo
Description:
Les progrès technologiques rapides dans le domaine de l’intelligence artificielle (IA), ainsi que d'autres avancées technologiques tels que la robotique, l’informatique en nuage et l'Internet des objets, transforment les disciplines, les économies, les industries et remettent en question ce que signifie d’être humain.
En Afrique, et particulièrement au Gabon, la compréhension, l’image, la bonne gouvernance de l'IA restent encore des défis importants de notre époque. Cela un apprentissage mutuel basé sur les leçons et les bonnes pratiques émergeant des différentes juridictions à travers le monde, en respectant les normes et standards mondiaux, et en étant ancrée dans la paix pour un développement durable. Madame Audrey Azoulay, Directrice Générale de l’UNESCO, soulignait encore à ce propos lors de la 41ème session de la Conférence générale que : « L’intelligence artificielle peut être une chance formidable pour accélérer la réalisation des objectifs de développement durable. Mais toute révolution technologique entraîne de nouveaux déséquilibres qu’il faut essayer d’anticiper ».
Après l’adoption de la Recommandation sur l’Ethique de l’Intelligence Artificielle, l’UNESCO a apporté son soutien aux différents Etats membres, dont le Gabon, dans le processus d’évaluation de l’état de préparation sur l’IA. Ce projet a pour objectif l’organisation d’un atelier de sensibilisation et d’appui à l’élaboration d’une stratégie nationale de l’IA pour impulser une transformation numérique en vue d’un développement durable au Gabon
Outcome EN: Enabling Outcome 10 - Reinforced partnerships, outreach and advocacy in support of UNESCO’s action
Output EN: 10.PPF1 - Participation Programme management significantly improved allowing greater transparency, timely coordination among sectors and responsiveness, and an increase in the number of projects approved for gender equality and countries in need, particul

Project: Formation et accompagnement des femmes en situation de précarité dans  l’entrepreneuriat
Description:
L’autonomisation sociale et économique de la femme a toujours été considérée comme un préalable, notamment depuis la Conférence mondiale des femmes de Beijing (Chine). Elle est d’autant plus préoccupante de nos jours qu’il est impératif d’impulser une nouvelle dynamique si nous voulons atteindre les objectifs visés par les ODD4 et ODD5.
L’ONG « Femmes Engagées dans la Lutte contre la Pauvreté pour un Avenir Meilleur » (FELUPAM) œuvre pour offrir aux femmes et aux jeunes filles vivant en situation de précarité des formations en entreprenariat dans les domaines d’activités de leurs choix pour améliorer leur situation économique et sociale. 
Par le projet « Formation et Accompagnement des Femmes en situation de précarité dans l’entrepreneuriat », nous voulons former, sensibiliser et encourager les femmes gabonaises vivant en situation de précarité dans la création des Activités Génératrices de Revenus (AGR) en vue de leur  autonomisation. Les objectifs de ce projet visent à la réduction de la pauvreté, l'égalité des sexes et la croissance économique pour un développement durable. À travers des témoignages inspirants, le projet favorise l'entrepreneuriat féminin. Il aspire à la transformation des vies des femmes, de leurs progénitures, ainsi que des communautés et à promouvoir un développement inclusif.
Outcome EN: Enabling Outcome 10 - Reinforced partnerships, outreach and advocacy in support of UNESCO’s action

Project: Workshop on Climate Change and Sustainable Development
Description:
Despite efforts to promote sustainable development, Liberia remains highly vulnerable to the impacts of climate change. The country’s long coastline and reliance on agriculture make it particularly susceptible to sea-level rise, storm surges, and changing rainfall patterns. These impacts pose significant challenges to the country’s development goals, including efforts to reduce poverty and promote economic growth. Moreover, it is proven that Liberia is facing numerous challenges related to climate change and sustainable development, including increasing frequency and severity of extreme weather events, deforestation, and limited access to clean water and energy, there is a lack of widespread awareness and capacity at the community level to address these issues effectively. Communities often lack the knowledge, resources, and support needed to develop and implement climate-resilient strategies and sustainable development practices. Additionally, there may be a disconnection between national policies and local priorities, hindering coordinated action at the grassroots level. Consequently, there is an urgent need to empower communities with the tools, information, and skills necessary to adapt to climate change, mitigate its impacts, and promote sustainable development practices that enhance resilience and improve livelihoods across Liberia.
To address some of these challenges, there is a need to build climate resilience and promote sustainable development at the community level. Community-based strategies can help to ensure that interventions are tailored to local needs and realities, while also empowering communities to take action to adapt to climate change and build resilience. However, there are significant barriers to implementing such strategies in Liberia, including limited resources, capacity gaps, and a lack of awareness and understanding of climate change issues among communities.

Project: TOT Workshops on the Preventions and Awareness of HIV/AIDS and Coronavirus for ASPnet Students and UNESCO Club Members
Description: Since there is no cure for either HIV/AIDS or coronavirus, preventive and awareness information should always be made available . Despite the information that there have been efforts to address HIV & AIDS and Coronavirus awareness in Liberia, there is a critical need for targeted interventions among ASPnet Students and UNESCO Club Members. These groups may lack comprehensive knowledge about preventive measures, transmission modes, and the importance of early detection for both HIV & AIDS and Coronavirus. Additionally, socio-cultural factors, stigma, and misinformation may contribute to the vulnerability of these populations. The overlapping risks and preventive strategies for HIV & AIDS and Coronavirus further emphasize the importance of a combined awareness workshop. Therefore, there is an urgent need to conduct workshops that specifically target ASPnet Students and UNESCO Club Members, providing them with accurate information, dispelling myths, and empowering them with the knowledge and skills necessary to protect themselves and their communities from both HIV & AIDS and Coronavirus. Moreover, HIV & AIDS and Coronavirus Prevention and Awareness Workshops for ASPnet Students and UNESCO Club Members in Liberia would typically outline the key issues that the workshop aims to address. In this case, the workshop would focus on highlighting the challenges and gaps in knowledge or awareness regarding HIV & AIDS and coronavirus among ASPnet students and UNESCO club members in Liberia. It would emphasize the importance of conducting a workshop to educate and raise awareness among these groups about prevention strategies, transmission modes, stigma reduction, and overall public health implications of these diseases.
Outcome EN: Enabling Outcome 10 - Reinforced partnerships, outreach and advocacy in support of UNESCO’s action

Project: Seminar on Research Methodology for University Lecturers in Liberia
Description: Despite the critical role of research methodology in producing high-quality academic research, many university lecturers in Liberia lack comprehensive knowledge and skills in advanced research methodologies. This knowledge gap hinders their ability to conduct rigorous research, publish impactful papers, and contribute significantly to their respective fields. Therefore, there is a pressing need to provide university lecturers with a specialized seminar on research methodology to enhance their research capabilities and ultimately improve the quality and quantity of academic output. Additionally, University lecturers in Liberia may lack adequate knowledge and skills in research methodology, which makes them ineffective in teaching and guiding students in conducting research. This gap in expertise could lead to subpar research outputs from students and faculty members, ultimately affecting the quality of education and research in Liberian universities.
Outcome EN: Enabling Outcome 10 - Reinforced partnerships, outreach and advocacy in support of UNESCO’s action
Output EN: 10.PPF1 - Participation Programme management significantly improved allowing greater transparency, timely coordination among sectors and responsiveness, and an increase in the number of projects approved for gender equality and countries in need, particul

Project: Promoting Reading Society in Liberia through National Book Fairs
Description: Despite the recognized benefits of fostering a culture of reading, Liberia faces challenges in promoting and sustaining a vibrant reading society. Factors such as limited access to diverse and affordable reading materials, low reading engagement levels, and a lack of community-based initiatives contribute to a diminished reading culture among the population. The absence of platforms like book fairs hinders the promotion of literacy, critical thinking, and intellectual growth. This gap not only affects individual development but also has broader implications for education, social cohesion, and cultural enrichment. Therefore, there is a pressing need to organize and promote book fairs as a means to encourage reading, improve access to a variety of literature, and cultivate a thriving reading society in Liberia. Moreover, Promoting Reading Society through Book Fairs in Liberia” revolves around the need to address the low literacy rates and lack of reading culture in Liberia. The objective is to promote a reading society by utilizing book fairs as a platform to engage the community, especially children and youth, in reading activities. This initiative aims to foster a culture of literacy, improve access to books, and encourage a love for reading among Liberians.

Project: Utilisation responsable des réseaux sociaux
Description:
Trois grandes activités seront prévues pour ce projet :
Une activité de plaidoyerqui a pour objectif principal de mobiliser l’attention des acteurs locaux et les parties prenantes en vue de l’éducation permanente des adolescents/jeunes sur l’utilisation des réseaux sociaux. 
La deuxième activité consiste à sensibiliser les jeunes sur « l’utilisation responsable des réseaux sociaux ». Sur ce, des adolescents/jeunes auront bénéficié des séances d’animation en salle dont la première partie concerne le téléphone portable (précaution technique et comportement convenable de son utilisateur) et l’autre partie sur les connaissances requises pour l’utilisation des réseaux sociaux ainsi que les règlements en vigueur applicable aux utilisateurs (lois sur la protection de la personne, charte de la communication, droit de diffusion des images et la cybercriminalité).
La troisième activité est une activité interactive du projet, par l’organisation des concours en trois volets : production de vidéo, présentation des talents, image de déviance positive.

Project: Enhance the role of the National Institute of Science and Technology for the Research Ethics Committee in Timor-Leste through National training workshop and Climate change activities in the classroom and Knua Prátika (lab) at 9 municipalities.
Description:
-	The National Institute of Science and Technology (INCT) as a public institute, Independent and autonomous body. INCT is in the process of establishing its Research Ethics Committee. The aim for the INCT to submit this proposal is to organize training to enhance the capacity of the Research Committee and other higher institutions. INCT also requests for UNESCO to provide training related to Research Ethics for the committee members. 
-	The Timor-Leste National Commission for UNESCO and its science division called SESIM have organized a workshop on climate change at the national level for around 100 teachers and pre-service teachers in the last three years. We have developed a supplementary material for the climate change manual which the teachers could use and integrate with the science discipline.  The objective of submitting this proposal is to continue training more teachers at the laboratories (Knua Prátika-KP) recently established in 9 municipalities. There will be more local teachers participating in the training, including hundreds of students where the KPs are located.

Project: International Coordinating Committee for the Safeguarding and Development of the Historic Sites of Angkor and Sambor Prei Kuk (ICC-Angkor/Sambor Prei Kuk)
Description: As follow-up of the decision of the First Intergovernmental Conference on Angkor, held in Tokyo in 1993, the working procedures of the Committee were established. It was decided that the ICC-Angkor would be co-chaired by France and Japan in collaboration with the APSARA National Authority, UNESCO provides the services of standing secretariat. The financial mechanism established on the initiative of Japan and France also foresaw that the cost of the ICC-Angkor meetings should be borne by these two countries and UNESCO. Respectively, since 2009, 2019, the APSARA and Sambor Prei Kuk National Authorities have also financially contributed to the ICC meetings. The Site of Sambor Prei Kuk, inscribed on the World Heritage List, was officially included in the mechanism of ICC-Angkor in 2019.
Outcome EN: Outcome 5 - Enhance the protection and promotion of the diversity of heritage and cultural expressions
Output EN: 5.CLT1 - Member States capacities strengthened to identify, protect and manage tangible heritage

Project: Fossil and Stratigraphy Identification to study on Paleo-environment of Sount-west Cambodia
Description:
In the wake of an extraordinary milestone in Cambodia's scientific narrative, the discovery and publication of the country's inaugural dinosaur fossil. this proposal, titled Fossil and Stratigraphy Identification to study on Paleo-environment of Sount-west Cambodia takes center stage. The preliminary study conducted by the Department of Heritage Park, the General Department of the local Community,  Ministry of Environment of Cambodia, unveils a fascinating revelation. Between the years 2019 and 2023, 59 fossil-rich locations have been identified in Banteay Meanchey, Battambang, Koh Kong, Strung Treng, Ratanakiri, Prah Vihear, Posat, and Siem Reap Provinces, as reported in the department's preliminary findings).

These identified locations boast a diverse array of fossil types, ranging from marine fossils to petrified woods, enigmatic footprints etched in time, and dinosaur skeletons that have been published in MPDI as international articles of fossil studies. The significance of this discovery reverberates through Cambodia's natural landscape, urging us to embark on an ambitious journey of exploration and identification.

Despite the richness of these fossil sites in Koh Kong and Kompot provinces, the details surrounding the fossils, biostratigraphy, and paleontology remain largely undocumented. The preliminary study underscores a critical gap in our understanding, primarily attributed to a lack of expertise and specialized equipment. In response, this proposal seeks to address and bridge these gaps, propelling Cambodia into a new era of scientific exploration and documentation.

Through meticulous identification, study, and documentation of these fossils, we aim to elevate Cambodia's standing in the global paleontological community. Furthermore, by nominating key fossil-rich sites for consideration on the UNESCO Global Geopark and /or World Heritage List for  Natural Heritage, Cambodia aspires to not only safeguard its paleontological treasures but also to contribute invaluable insights to the broader understanding of Earth's ancient history.
Outcome EN: Enabling Outcome 10 - Reinforced partnerships, outreach and advocacy in support of UNESCO’s action
Output EN: 10.PPF1 - Participation Programme management significantly improved allowing greater transparency, timely coordination among sectors and responsiveness, and an increase in the number of projects approved for gender equality and countries in need, particul

Project: Research, Compilation and Exhibition of Intangible Heritages (Traditional Festivals) Around the Temple Complex of Sambor Prei Kuk, Kampong Thom Province
Description: The submission of this project aims to contribute to the protection of the intangible cultural heritage around the temple complex of Sambor Prei Kuk, which is facing constant loss. The traditional festivals of the locals around this area, whether Khmer or Kuoy ethnic group, all show a unique culture different from other areas in Cambodia that should not be overlooked. The research and compilation to publish of an inventory book and the storing of these data on the website, as well as the installation of an exhibition on intangible cultural heritage in the Kampong Thom provincial museum, that are part of this project could be a great way to protect these heritages. It is an image to promote, value and motivate people in the community to continue to worship this valuable cultural resource and it is a significant part of helping the general public to freely explore this cultural heritage.
Outcome EN: Enabling Outcome 10 - Reinforced partnerships, outreach and advocacy in support of UNESCO’s action

Project: Adapting guidelines on use of technology in education in Vietnam
Description:
The goal of UNESCO’s support under this workplan is to contribute to strengthening the national capacity in planning and building a technology-enabled inclusive and resilient school system in Viet Nam, by introducing and adapting the framework and guidelines developed by UNESCO.   

It is proposed that at least one of UNESCO's relevant recent guidelines (tentatively Guidance for Use of Generative AI in Education and Research) is translated from English to Vietnamese and adapted to the Vietnamese context; the documents will serve as key guiding documents to help identify opportunities and challenges and for policy discussion on next steps. UNESCO will also support the consultation process to this effect. 

In addition, it is planned that a launching event for the Southeast Asia regional edition of the Global Education Monitoring Report on Technology and Education is organized with key partners (e.g. MOET in particular Department of ICT and Vietnam National Institute of Educational Sciences) with involvement of the members of the Education Sector Group in the country in view of raising awareness and involving various stakeholders and partners in relevant discussion.
Outcome EN: Outcome 8 - Foster knowledge sharing and skills development in the digital age
Output EN: 8.ED8 - Technologies and digital innovations leveraged to ensure more inclusive, effective and relevant learning

Project: Strengthening Safety of Journalists in the Context of Election in the
Description: The aim of this project is to create a safe space for journalists in covering the general election in the Philippines by encouraging press freedom and access to information in the era of disinformation. This goal will be achieved by providing capacity building for journalists in the Philippines regarding the general election that includes understanding the general election process and regulations that applied in the 2022 general election. Therefore, journalists will have a strong base of understanding, equipped with a groundwork of fact checks, and data-based journalism skills, as well as safety journalist background (physical and digital).
Outcome EN: Outcome 6 - Promote freedom of expression and the right to information
Output EN: 6.CI2 - Member States have strengthened capacities and raised awareness to enhance norms and policies related to freedom of expression, press freedom, safety of journalists, including women journalists, and the right to access information, online and offl

Project: Strengthening Legal Education and Institutional Capacity through the Development of an Internal Quality Assurance Framework at JSW Law
Description:
Established in February 2015 under a Royal Charter, Jigme Singye Wangchuck School of Law (JSW Law) is Bhutan's first and only law school, embodying the vision of His Majesty the King and the legacy of  'Justice, Service, Wisdom.' The school, led by Her Royal Highness, Princess Sonam Dechan Wangchuck, has become a pioneer in legal education with a unique five-year Bachelor of Law/Postgraduate Diploma in National Law program. JSW Law actively contributes to Bhutan's Social Development Plan, particularly focusing on Outcome 2: "More Bhutanese equitably access and benefit from quality and wholesome education and lifelong learning by 2029." Aligned with national goals and UNESCO's mission for quality education and recognizing the importance of a dynamic education system, JSW Law envisions integrating a robust Internal Quality Assurance (IQA) framework across its operations to ensure quality, relevance, and responsiveness. 

Despite commendable achievements within a short period of its establishment, His Majesty emphasized the need for expansion beyond the LL.B./PGDNL, urging JSW Law to broaden its focus. In terms of Quality Assurance, JSW Law faces a few challenges that hinder the establishment of a robust IQA framework. One significant challenge is the lack of expertise in IQA within the institution. As a relatively young and pioneering law school in Bhutan, JSW Law does not have a dedicated pool of professionals with specialized knowledge in quality assurance processes. This shortage of expertise poses a significant challenge in developing and implementing an effective IQA mechanism. Furthermore, the institution is confronted with financial constraints inherent to its developmental phase. The lack of budget limits the school’s capacity to invest in training, technology, and other resources necessary for the successful implementation of a comprehensive IQA framework. Addressing these challenges is crucial for JSW Law to continue advancing its vision and mission, ensuring the sustained delivery of high-quality legal education in Bhutan. 

Recognizing the critical role of Internal Quality Assurance in maintaining and enhancing educational standards, this proposal seeks to establish a comprehensive Internal Quality Assurance mechanism at JSW Law. Additionally, it proposes a targeted capacity-building initiative tailored for JSW Law to develop and implement a robust IQA framework.
Outcome EN: Enabling Outcome 10 - Reinforced partnerships, outreach and advocacy in support of UNESCO’s action
Output EN: 10.PPF1 - Participation Programme management significantly improved allowing greater transparency, timely coordination among sectors and responsiveness, and an increase in the number of projects approved for gender equality and countries in need, particul

Project: Capacity Building Workshop for Focal Points of ASPnet and UNESCO Clubs in Bhutan
Description:
The Bhutan National Commission for UNESCO has spearheaded the establishment of ASPnet and UNESCO clubs since 2006, with remarkable growth to 102 UNESCO Clubs and 109 ASPnet Schools by 2023. These entities serve as crucial advocates for UNESCO's principles while enhancing its visibility. Focal Points play a pivotal role in advancing UNESCO's mission through various activities. Efforts have been made to train teachers and coordinators through workshops, enabling the effective propagation of UNESCO's ideals.

To further strengthen capacity, a comprehensive workshop series is proposed, aiming to empower coordinators with the knowledge and skills to implement activities aligned with UNESCO's mission and Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Through cascading training from national to local levels, the project seeks to foster collaboration, knowledge sharing, and resource mobilization among stakeholders.

The project anticipates a deeper understanding and commitment to UNESCO's mission, heightened awareness of its global impact, and enhanced engagement in initiatives promoting sustainable development and cultural preservation. Sustainability is prioritized through equipping Focal Points to continue advocacy and initiative implementation beyond the project's duration. Partnerships with educational institutions, NGOs, and other stakeholders will enrich the program and ensure its success.
Outcome EN: Enabling Outcome 10 - Reinforced partnerships, outreach and advocacy in support of UNESCO’s action
Output EN: 10.PPF1 - Participation Programme management significantly improved allowing greater transparency, timely coordination among sectors and responsiveness, and an increase in the number of projects approved for gender equality and countries in need, particul

Project: Promoting Freedom of Expression and Safety of Journalists
Description:
Bangladesh’s media landscape has undergone rapid changes, also facing numerous challenges. Promoting the safety of journalists and the fight against impunity according to the UN Plan of Action (UNPA) with the aims to prevent, protect and support the prosecution of journalists from threats, harassment and violent attacks, and end impunity for the crimes is essential. The longer-term goal of this work plan is to build a wide coalition supporting Press Freedom, starting with NGOs and Embassies and Govt. at some stage.

While media has played pivotal roles in the development of Bangladesh, there exists political complex. To establish a connection between press freedom, freedom of expression, and other rights, the UNESCO office in Dhaka intends to link it with other rights and actively promote the safety of journalists. Also giving focus on the safety of women journalists. This will create an atmosphere that supports freedom of expression amidst evolving digital challenges.
Outcome EN: Outcome 6 - Promote freedom of expression and the right to information
Output EN: 6.CI2 - Member States have strengthened capacities and raised awareness to enhance norms and policies related to freedom of expression, press freedom, safety of journalists, including women journalists, and the right to access information, online and offl

Project: Promoting Media and Information Literacy in Bangladesh
Description:
The awareness and advocacy work plan for Media and Information Literacy (MIL) in Bangladesh addresses the urgent need to enhance MIL skills among media organizations, journalists, educational institutions, youth groups, civil society organizations involving relevant government bodies and UN agencies.
The focus will be on solution-oriented actions to tackle disinformation, hate speech, and racism, while promoting freedoms, gender equality, and peacebuilding. Collaboration with stakeholders will facilitate the regular celebration of Global Media and Information Literacy Week. This plan aims to empower journalists to critically evaluate media content and foster an informed society by promoting MIL awareness and advocating its importance.  
Leveraging the digital revolution, the vision includes transforming targeted cities into "MIL Cities," aligning with Bangladesh's Smart Bangladesh Vision 2041, which emphasizes the development of Smart Citizens, Smart Government, Smart Economy, and Smart Society.
Outcome EN: Outcome 8 - Foster knowledge sharing and skills development in the digital age
Output EN: 8.IP4 (CI) - National capacities strengthened to empower learners of all ages, women and men, with digital competencies and Media and Information Literacy skills

Project: Study of Floristic Composition of Lawachara and Satchari forests with special emphasis on the conservation status of two Reserved Forests of Bangladesh.
Description: The Lawachara and Satchari- two reserve forests in Bangladesh are rich in invaluable plant resources. They are also abode of rare birds and animals. In recent years, there has been increasing use of resources of the forests including rise of ecotourism in these areas. At this backdrop, the objective of this project is to study the floristic composition of these forests, mapping the forests and assess the conservation status with a view to ensure sustainable use of resources by the forest goers and users. The project aims to raise awareness about the importance of conserving these forests' biodiversity among the stakeholders and ultimately to prepare an application for Biosphere Reserve.

Project: Socio-Economic Survey of the Bauls of  Bangladesh
Description: The project aims to conduct a comprehensive Socio-Economic Survey of the Bauls of Bangladesh, an indigenous musical and spiritual community. Focusing on their unique cultural heritage, the survey will explore their socio-economic conditions, preserving traditional practices while addressing contemporary challenges. By documenting their lifestyle, art, and economic activities, the project seeks to promote cultural preservation, community empowerment, and sustainable development. This initiative aligns with UNESCO's commitment to safeguarding intangible cultural heritage and fostering inclusive growth within diverse communities. Through collaboration and research, the Socio-Economic Survey intends to contribute valuable insights for both local empowerment and global cultural understanding.

Project: Kazakhstan's Diplomacy and Overseas Relationship in 15th – 17th centuries: Introducing the New Artifacts from Overseas Museums and Archives and Shaping the Scholar's Vision (International Conference and round table)
Description: The project aims to assist Kazakhstan and Central Asian States in applying social and human scientific frontier knowledge in recovering the national history and ethnic identity. For two recent decades Kazakhstan academicians and scholars have identified in the museums' collections and archives a significant number of documents and material objects related to the history of the Kazakh Khanate in 15th – 17th centuries. It is necessary to focus active discussions of the newly identified archival documents and artifacts to shape adequately the Kazakhstan sovereignty historical concept. The conference will involve the knowledgeable international academic community in renewal of the Kazakhstan history.

Project: Three Day Workshop on Cultural (and National Heritage) Policy   Development
Description:
The idea of the preservation of natural and cultural heritage has entered into the international arena with the adoption of the ‘Convention Concerning the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage in 1972. This convention was introduced considering the global context that disturbs or harms the cultural and natural heritages in the world. Therefore, this proposed project will cover the subject area that was emphasized by the 1972 convention. 
Even Though government has paid more attention to the culture and heritage sector, absence of a national policy for culture and heritage to ensure the long-lasting safeguard of the sector is a critical issue. Hence, the main objective of the proposed project is to to develop a national policy for the Cultural and National Heritage sector in Sri Lanka through a residential workshop. 
Since the culture and heritage are a very sensitive and dynamic area, policy preparation to satisfy all stakeholders is a challenge. Therefore, this workshop will be designed as a three-day residential workshop and includes consultation sessions with the participation of relevant stakeholders in the public sector, private sector and NGO sector. It is expected to have around 40 participants for the workshop.
Facilitation of the reputed resource person who has both national and international experience on making cultural and heritage policy will be taken to conduct the workshop. Especially his experiences and active participation in UNESCO, will be an additional valuve for success for the task. During the workshop, the first draft of the national policy document will be done and shared among all stakeholders to obtain their comments and opinion. As the final output of the project there will be a policy document for the culture and heritage sector in Sri Lanka.
Outcome EN: Enabling Outcome 10 - Reinforced partnerships, outreach and advocacy in support of UNESCO’s action
Output EN: 10.PPF1 - Participation Programme management significantly improved allowing greater transparency, timely coordination among sectors and responsiveness, and an increase in the number of projects approved for gender equality and countries in need, particul

Project: An analysis of barriers to Sri Lankan women’s human capital accumulation in STEM subjects
Description: Human capital accumulation extends from general education from school years to training in job markets. While gender gaps in education and labor market outcomes for women in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) has improved, women still face various challenges in selecting STEM at school levels and transitioning to employment following their education. This study explores the barriers at both the school level as students make decisions on STEM subject selection and at the level of entrance to the labor market following the completion of tertiary education.

Project: FIR ASSESSMENT AND TRAINING, LEVUKA WORLD HERITAGE SITE
Description:
The Fiji Department of Culture, Heritage and Arts, and the Fiji National Fire Authority have prepared a proposal to reduce fire risk to the World Heritage Town of Levuka, Fiji. This includes: 
- Previewing the Levuka Heritage Resister and Values.
- Identify fire protection and life safety objectives.
- Identify fire Hazards.
- Determine the best solutions for protection that meet safety objectives and regulations while minimizing impact on the attributes of the World Heritage Town.
This will be conducted through assessments, planning workshops with key stakeholders, by fire management experts from NFA, who will link into their pool of national and international experts.

Project: Workshop on Traditional House/Shelter (An exchange of traditional knowledge and skills and expertise)
Description: Vanuatu is a country that is prone to natural disasters. Tropical cyclones are a common occurrence in the country with a high prevalence (cyclone season) between the months of November in the previous year to April of the following year. Vanuatu’s cultures and traditions also revolve around these seasons, where crops are harvested and planted before and after the cyclone season, food is preserved for natural disasters, traditional structures are built that can withstand cyclone as seen when TC PAM struck in 2015, bringing with it a nationwide disaster especially in the two southern provinces of Shefa and Tafea. Although there were destruction to the gardens and structures, there were a significant amount of traditional structures that were used as evacuation centers and that withstood the destructive winds.

Project: The 26th Consultation Meeting of the Pacific Heads of Education Systems (PHES)
Description:
The Pacific Heads of Education Systems (PHES) constitutes a network comprising the highest-ranking officials from the ministries of education across 15 Pacific Small Island Developing Nations (SIDS). The primary objectives of PHES are fourfold: (i) fostering coordination among national education systems by identifying shared solutions; (ii) facilitating SIDS-SIDS or South-South and triangular cooperation; (iii) supporting the professional development of member states; and (iv) advocating for education standards and outcomes aligned with global and regional education goals and targets. PHES conducts assessments of educational needs spanning basic to higher education and lifelong learning, encompassing continuing education, technical and vocational education and training (TVET), while also aiding in the development of pertinent programming and offering guidance to the broader education sector.
Consultation Meetings of PHES occur biennially, preceding the Conference of Pacific Education Ministers (CPEM), with each Pacific Island country taking turns to host.

It recognizes the Government of Niue’s ongoing efforts to the promotion of UNESCO Cultural Conventions Niue is party to but most importantly the importance of sustaining and strengthening Niue culture, Vagahau Niue language, value and identity which are at risk from climate change, migration and modernization. Vagahau Niue, the key vehicle to the transmission of Niue intangible cultural heritage is listed as definitely endangered and participating at key regional events like FestPAC provide opportunities for Niue artists in various artforms is an opportunity to share with other similar Pacific countries and find solutions to sustain our language, identity and values.

Through the workshop, the participants will be acquainted with the major educational technologies and the best ICT practices currently available for teachers across the world and the ways which make teachers capable of taking a more effective role in ensuring equitable use of technology and creating world-class educational digital content and capacity. It is supposed this event would provide an opportunity to recover the current situation of ICT’s application in Education in Iran and develop the academic networks for collaboration and partnership to promote new technologies in school and teacher education and training, in the country.

Project: Evaluating and Protecting Rarotonga's Key Ecosystems: Stream Health and the Preservation of the Last Fiddler Crab Habitats
Description:
Our initiative seeks to safeguard Rarotonga's ecosystems by conducting detailed stream
health assessments and conserving the last remaining fiddler crab habitat. Collaborating with
educational and environmental experts, we aim to establish a scientific baseline for ecological
integrity, inform targeted restoration, and engage youth through hands-on research and media.
The project intertwines community education with scientific rigor, utilizing SHMAK kits and
eDNA analysis. We require financial support for specialist expertise, educational materials, and
essential monitoring equipment to ensure the vitality of our streams, the survival of native
species, and the cultivation of environmental stewardship among the next generation.

Description: Children with ASD emerged as the most excluded group as the services and support addressing their needs are limited in the country. People with autism lack communication and social interaction. The integration of children with autism has been an important and controversial issue in the educational community (general and special education). The risk of poor school adaptation for these children exacerbates the poor adaptive behavior of these children and thus integration becomes more difficult. Teachers and support staff are the key to the effective integration of children with autism and their attitude and behavior are very important.

Project: Etude pour la mise en place d’une base de données sensibles au genre dans les domaines des science, technologie et innovation (STI) et de la recherche développement (R&D) au Togo
Description: La disponibilité en temps opportun de données de qualité sur les STI et la recherche-développement est fondamentale pour définir des politiques et stratégies pertinentes pour faire de ces dernières un levier de développement. Malheureusement, hormis quelques données parcellaires produites de façon isolée par certaines structures de recherche, le pays ne dispose pas de données actualisées et désagrégées selon le genre pour apprécier les progrès réalisés dans le sous-secteur et surtout pour déterminer la contribution réelle de la recherche et de l’innovation au développement du pays. Dès lors, collecter, traiter, analyser et diffuser des données de base actualisées permettra de mettre à la disposition des décideurs et des acteurs du sous-secteur des données sensibles au genre utiles à la prise de décision.

Project: Camp de sciences à l'intention des jeunes filles scolaires
Description: Si de nos jours le nombre de filles scolarisées est de plus en plus important, on fait face à une disparité entre filles et garçons dans les filières scientifiques et techniques en raison des stéréotypes liés au genre et les considérations culturelles qui font que le sexe féminin s’éloigne des disciplines de la science, de la technologie, de l’ingénierie et des mathématiques. Le projet camp des sciences cherche à encourager la participation, la poursuite et l’achèvement des études des filles togolaises dans lesdites filières afin de réduire les inégalités de genre dans les professions scientifiques et technologiques.
Outcome EN: Enabling Outcome 10 - Reinforced partnerships, outreach and advocacy in support of UNESCO’s action

Project: Appui à la restauration et à la valorisation de la biodiversité des îlots de forêts communautaires du sud-est de la réserve de biosphère du Mono au Togo
Description: Les activités du présent projet proposé permettront de renforcer l’inclusion des communautés locales environnantes des îlots de forêts du terroir d’Avévé dans la gestion et la conservation de la biodiversité à travers le renforcement des capacités et le renforcement de la résilience des femmes et des jeunes. Ce projet est initié dans le cadre de la mise en œuvre du plan d’aménagement du complexe d’îlots de forêts communautaires AFOMADZEAVE du terroir Avévé et complète le financement actuellement en cours sous le projet WACA « Appui à la mise en œuvre du plan d’aménagement et de Gestion des complexes de forêts communautaires d’Avévé : reboisement de 50 ha»

Project: CONSERVATION, VALORISATION ET SAUVEGARDE DES FOSSILES DU BASSIN SEDIMENTAIRE COTIER DU TOGO (CVSF_BSCT).
Description: Le Projet de conservation, valorisation et sauvegarde des fossiles du bassin sédimentaire côtier du Togo (CVSF_BSCT) est né d’un constat de la mauvaise conservation et de la dispersion du patrimoine paléontologique togolais. Ce patrimoine d’une valeur inestimable (restes de tortues, crocodiles, requins, raies, serpents, ancêtres d’éléphants et baleines archaïques…), d’âge compris entre 59 et 40 Millions d’années, découvert dans le bassin sédimentaire côtier du Togo est en danger alors qu’il présente des intérêts scientifiques, pédagogiques et géotouristique pour le Togo. Il urge l’aménagement une salle de conservation pour la sauvegarde et la valorisation de ce patrimoine.

Project: Scaling Participation of Creative Cultural Industries Practitioners for Strategic Market Access
Description: UNESCO highlights the vulnerabilities of the culture sector exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic, emphasizing the risks to cultural heritage and the challenges faced globally. Lesotho, facing potential cultural appropriation, aims to capitalize on its diverse cultural heritage for economic development through Creative Cultural Industries (CCI). While Lesotho has been active in fashion, there's a need to enhance participation in music, film, and food systems. The project focuses on learning and capacity building to promote entrepreneurship, cultural appreciation, and global market positioning. Lessons from a film production project underscore the gender disparities in powerful positions within CCI, especially in the film industry. The project aims to address this by identifying and empowering women in key roles, fostering wide consultation, and creating a pipeline for cultural creativity to access local and international markets.
Outcome EN: Enabling Outcome 10 - Reinforced partnerships, outreach and advocacy in support of UNESCO’s action
Output EN: 10.PPF1 - Participation Programme management significantly improved allowing greater transparency, timely coordination among sectors and responsiveness, and an increase in the number of projects approved for gender equality and countries in need, particul

Project: BICE- Appui à la Scolarisation des Enfants Vulnérables à Bopa, Bénin
Description: Dans le but de mettre en œuvre le droit à l’éducation et de prévenir différentes formes d’exploitation, le projet vise à favoriser la scolarisation en primaire et secondaire des enfants vulnérables vivant dans la commune de Bopa, sud-est du Bénin ainsi que leur maintien à l’école. Ceci en les dotant de kits scolaires et vestimentaires, en appuyant une cantine, en engageant des enseignants qualifiés, et en réalisant deux réunions de plaidoyer pour que les autorités politiques œuvrent davantage pour l’accès à l’éducation en milieu rural.

Project: ACWW-Planting the Seeds of Peace
Description: This training project will empower Ukrainian refugee students and women teachers in the Educational Hub hosted by Școala Gimnazialǎ “Uruguay”. It will strengthen the capacities and resilience of survivors of violence and war with practical tools, helping them become builders of a safer, happier future grounded in human rights and gender equality.  Horticultural training will address trauma caused by conflict and displacement. By supporting a conscious approach to horticulture and life on earth, it builds on the understanding that gardening reduces stress, anxiety, and depression and improves psychological wellbeing. Horticulture classes and practical sessions will run throughout the year.

Project: CLADE- Capacity building program in follow-up of the Marrakech Framework for Action: contributions to ALE public policy in the subregions of Central America and the Andes.
Description: This capacity building proposal seeks, fundamentally, to transform a global policy document, such as the Marrakech Framework for Action (MFA), into a tool for practical application in public policies and Adult Learning Education -ALE programs which are in place in the selected countries. In this way, it will strengthen the analysis with a rights-based approach and the use of this tool for the improvement of such policies and programs. Finally, it seeks to strengthen the capacities of the technical staff responsible for the execution and/or direct coordination of such programs in the ministries of education so that their daily work contributes to the advancement of the MFA.

Project: CCIVS- Youth Empowerment for Climate Action: Bridging Global Perspectives through International Engagement
Description:
The proposal aims to fortify youth activism against climate change through international volunteering and advocacy. It plans an international seminar for CCIVS Youth Committee members  https://ccivs.org/ccivs- youth-committee/
 , followed by participation in the International Forum of NGOs at UNESCO. The goal is to empower young activists to engage with NGOs and UNESCO, shaping future programs and understanding the role of International Voluntary Service in climate justice. With a focus on inclusion, diversity, and global cooperation, the seminar targets skill development, policy understanding, and intercultural exchange. It aims for tangible outcomes, fostering youth leadership and collaborative efforts towards climate action and social justice. The results will feed into future CCIVS projects on this topic.

Project: OMEP-The toy libraries project: learning life through play
Description:
The Toy Libraries project is a high impact, cost effective, programme that gives children, their families, early ECD practitioners and early learning facilitators access to a collection of carefully selected educational and play materials, play spaces and training on how to use these toys to enhance development. 
The main objective of this project is to provide easily accessible quality early learning opportunities for children by establishing a toy library at their reach. Building on OMEP Kenya's previous experience for more than 10 years, this project would empower other countries to set up toy libraries and continue developing current proposals that aim to strengthen the right to play
