Project: World Space Day Celebration Week
Description:
World Space Week has been officially declared by the United Nations as the annual week from 4 to 10 October. It is an international celebration of the contribution of space science and technology to improving the human condition. The dates that mark World Space Week commemorate landmark events of the space age: on 4 October 1957, Sputnik I, the first man-made Earth satellite, was launched. The Treaty on the Peaceful Exploration of Outer Space was signed by UN member states on 10 October 1967.
The celebration of World Space Week is an excellent opportunity to highlight the achievements and potential of space exploration on a global level. World Space Week usually takes place in October and involves a variety of activities, including talks, workshops, exhibitions, competitions and much more.
On 4 October 1957, the launch into outer space of the first man-made Earth satellite, Sputnik 1, paved the way for space exploration. A decade later, on 10 October 1967, the Treaty on the Principles Governing the Activities of States in the Exploration and Use of Outer Space, including the Moon and Other Celestial Bodies entered into force.
Space science and technology and their applications are increasingly being used to support a wide range of United Nations activities. At least 25 United Nations entities and the World Bank Group routinely use space applications. They make important and sometimes essential contributions to the work of the United Nations, including in implementing the recommendations of major world conferences and the Third United Nations Conference on the Exploration and Peaceful Uses of Outer Space (UNISPACE III), as well as in supporting sustainable development.
Since the dawn of the Space Age, the United Nations has recognised that outer space has added a new dimension to humanity's existence. The United Nations family continually strives to utilise the unique benefits of outer space for the betterment of all humanity.
Recognising humanity's common interest in outer space and seeking to answer questions about how outer space can help benefit the peoples of the Earth, the General Assembly adopted its first resolution related to outer space, resolution 1348 (XIII) entitled "Question of the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space".

Project: Entrepreneurship Empowering young men, girls and students to participate in entrepreneurship using communications and information technology in the modern era, and to contribute to achieving sustainable development goals.
Description:
Introduction
The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) gives great attention to building a society of knowledge and information, inclusive of all, to achieve sustainable development, innovation and leadership in the use of communication and information technology for the purposes of education and entrepreneurship, and ensuring that everyone’s equal participation in the development of society is an essential factor in achieving: 
	The fourth goal of sustainable development, which is related to the quality of education, 
	The fifth goal, which considers gender equality, 
	The ninth goal, which relates to industry and innovation; by strengthening industry and innovation, new economic opportunities can be provided, and increase and speed of access to sources of information and technology can be available, which enhances economic development and contributes to protection of fundamental freedoms.
	The tenth goal, which relates to alleviating gaps in societies and between countries, 
	The seventeenth goal, which relates to partnerships to achieve the goals. 

This aims to enhance international cooperation and partnerships between the public and private sectors and civil society, to achieve the goals of sustainable development, including the protection of freedoms, and providing access to information for all. This is to enhance the capabilities of young people, achieve the principle of universal access to information, and provide opportunities for comprehensive, equitable quality education and lifelong learning for all, and for the different marginalized and vulnerable groups (women, girls, youth, and people with special needs).
The progress achieved in the field of communications and information technology and the increasing interconnectedness between the societies of knowledge will enhance work to advance innovation, entrepreneurship, renovation, and creating new job opportunities for youth, women, and girls to improve the standard of their living and income. Open resources programs of information and technology provide the opportunity to support and empower developing countries and all individuals and society. They also ensures social and economic inclusion for all, which contributes to achieving sustainable development goals and reducing the percentage of young people deprived of jobs, education or training opportunities.
The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) has a major role in enhancing the effective contribution of women and girls in the field of using communication and information technology in the fields of education, science and culture. Due to people’s increasing reliance on digital technological means, the use of social media creates opportunities of work for young people, and at the same time creates great challenges. Opportunities that can be seized in this regard include social learning, innovation, knowledge exchange, democratic participation, and intercultural dialogue. One of the most important challenges that must be addressed is the spread of misinformation and widespread disinformation, which directly affects young people as the main users of the internet and social media globally.
Through this project, the Egyptian National Committee, as a link between the UNESCO and the concerned parties, will contribute to building an inclusive society of knowledge and information to achieve sustainable development by creating a specialized training package in entrepreneurship and making good use of modern technology and artificial intelligence tools to qualify young people for the labor market and increase their capabilities for compete globally.
Through this project, the Egyptian National Committee will provide partnerships and cooperation between:

1. Educational institutions and teachers who play an essential role in enhancing media and information literacy among learners and enabling them to acquire the necessary competencies to participate in the digital field as global citizens. It will take place at all levels of primary and secondary education, as well as in the field of adult learning.
2. Youth organizations, young people and especially young women; young people are the most active users of digital technologies, therefore it is necessary to ensure that they acquire the necessary digital competencies in the field of media and information literacy, and to ensure their ability to have effective entrepreneurship that enables them to create the desired impact to face the challenges related to the development of this field. So, the necessary measures will be taken to achieve the following:
•	Enabling young people to acquire competencies in the field of media, information literacy and digital competencies and using them as peer educators
•	Enhancing the capacity of youth-led organizations to integrate media and information literacy into their activities, policies and strategies through means that include encouraging intercultural dialogue to achieve understanding;
•	Supporting effective youth actions that enable young people to find the necessary solutions and play an active role as they are able to bring about the desired change in order to achieve social inclusion and combat all forms of exclusion, racism and discrimination in the digital field;
•	Assuring that young people’s use of digital technologies, and the impact of these means on them is part and parcel of comprehensive youth development approaches in youth policies;
•	Enhancing science-based youth organizations to have the desired impact in decision-making processes;
•	Relying on advances and developments in the field of neurotechnology to find solutions to serious mental health problems.

3. Media institutions and media workers; by establishing partnerships with digital communications platforms as principal actors to integrate media and information literacy in digital spaces.
Working with the above-mentioned groups, the necessary links will be created between them to put relevant tools on digital learning and guidelines on digital citizenship into practice. This is to cope with UNESCO’s endeavors to take gender equality into account as one of its main areas of focus, while recognizing the digital gap that exists between men and women, which prevents women and girls from benefiting from digital technology and participating in the digital field through engaging men and boys as responsible allies to advance gender equality in the digital sphere.
“71% of young people worldwide are connected to the Internet, compared to 57% of the total population.”
International Telecommunication Union.

https://www.itu.int/en/ITU-D/Statistics/Pages/facts/default.aspx (2022) 2 اليونيسف. ( ) https://www.unicef.org/media/123626/file/UNICEF_Recovering_Learning_Report_EN.pdf.pdf       2022
https://www.unesco.org/en/articles/scaling-digital-learning-and-skills-worlds-most-populous-countries-drive-education-recove
This will help the concerned authorities integrate in providing overall solutions for young people to confront economic conditions, and benefit from information, open source software, and modern artificial intelligence tools, and harness digital technological means to build peace and achieve sustainable development and build inclusive knowledge societies, through the use of open solutions (open educational resources, open access and open data);
This project enhances the contribution to the Information for All program and contributes to the endeavors aimed at achieving the two goals; universal access to information and inclusion of all in the digital era.

Project: Together Towards a Greening Education for Sustainable Development.
Description:
Greening education is one that seeks sustainable development, keeping pace with technological development and benefiting from it in all elements of the educational process with high efficiency and distinct outcomes, according to environmentally friendly standards. It develops environmental programs such as buildings, energy, afforestation, and services. It also focuses on the educational process and providing it with related technologies, applications, strategies, and practices. The concept of green education. 

Greening education also allows effective use of modern educational technologies, which has the greatest impact on: - Quality education, expanding the student’s awareness, and direct and active communication between the student and the teacher. - Developing his creativity and exploration skills and moving away from the traditional learning routine. - Informing the student’s guardian continuously and accurately about his child’s academic level. - Transforming traditional classrooms into a virtual world that simulates reality. - Creating an interactive space with exciting and enriching possibilities for the student’s thinking and knowledge at the same time and in a healthy and safe environment.

So, this project consists of implementing national trainings and initiatives in formal  and non-formal education.

Il vise à mettre en place un processus de mobilisation communautaire et d’accompagnement de la population sur la prévention et la gestion des feux de forêt.

Project: Formación y sensibilización Integral para la Sostenibilidad y resiliencia ambiental y cultural que comprende reciclaje, huertos orgánicos y obras de conservación de suelo y agua en 8 comunidades de Suchitoto.
Description: El Proyecto comprende la formación y sensibilización en la defensa de los bienes naturales y su uso sostenible, así como, la resiliencia ambiental comprendiendo la economía circular, implementación de huertos orgánicos y conservación de suelo y agua, con técnicas de permacultura, en 8 comunidades.  Las familias de las comunidades de Suchitoto son de escasos recursos y su principal fuente de ingresos son actividades agrícolas, donde se le dará preminencia a la mujer, ya que las mayoría de mujeres están al frente de sus hogares, realizando actividades agropecuarias, sin embargo, se encuentran en condiciones desiguales en cuanto al acceso a la tierra. Para tener acceso, se conformarán comités de mujeres, jóvenes, niños, niñas, centros comunitarios y sus respectivos centros escolares del municipio de Suchitoto, donde además se fomentará la cultura entre los jóvenes de los centros educativos mediante la expresión ecológica en murales en sus centros educativos.

Project: Fortalecimiento de las habilidades de educadores y educadoras de la EPJA. Hacia la  circulación social, la participación igualitaria y la cultura: la ciudad como ambiente de  aprendizaje
Description:
El proyecto se propone difundir y sensibilizar en el país la importancia de la Educación de 
Personas Jóvenes y Adultas (EPJA) de acuerdo a la definición aprobada en la Recomendación 
sobre el Aprendizaje y la Educación de Adultos, Conferencia General de la UNESCO, Reunión 38ª 
Adoptada el 13 de noviembre de 2015 y las orientaciones acordadas en la VII Conferencia 
Internacional de Educación de Adultos (CONFINTEA) en el Marco de Acción de Marrakech:
“Aprovechar el poder transformador del aprendizaje y la educación de adultos” el Objetivo de 
Desarrollo Sustentable 4: “Garantizar una educación inclusiva, equitativa y de calidad y promover 
oportunidades de aprendizaje durante toda la vida para todos”, contemplado en la Agenda 2030 
de Naciones Unidas.
En este sentido, a partir de estos contenidos fundamentales, se procurará adecuarlos a las 
necesidades e intereses de los diferentes territorios del país, donde trabajan educadoras y 
educadores, en un país donde no se cuenta con una formación específica en EPJA.
Por lo tanto, es necesario, entonces relevar el estado de situaciones particulares a tener en cuenta 
en el diseño de los diferentes módulos que integran el ciclo formativo.
Se prestará especial atención a quienes trabajan:
- en la enseñanza de las personas que no han culminado la enseñanza primaria y media; 
- con mujeres, especialmente aquellas que cursen o desean cursar formación técnica, profesional 
y superior;
- con personas jóvenes, adultas y adultas mayores, especialmente quienes desean adquirir 
competencias técnicas y profesionales, para acceder al empleo, el trabajo decente y el 
emprendedurismo;
- con personas que se encuentran en situación de vulnerabilidad.
Se relevará, sistematizará y dará respuestas a las demandas formativas de colectivos locales del 
interior del país, a través del desarrollo de acciones formativas en educación ciudadana para 
educadores/as, atendiendo a las dificultades de las personas jóvenes y adultas de esa región para 
acceder y sostener aprendizajes más allá del sistema formal de educación, donde los grupos 
postergados y vulnerables, en particular, mujeres y jóvenes, son los más afectados. 
Para responder a estas necesidades se elaborará y ofrecerá, en este primer año y con la 
posibilidad de ser reeditado en el futuro, una propuesta de educación virtual de alcance nacional, 
focalizada en los contenidos que ha sistematizado la Cátedra UNESCO EPJA en Uruguay 
teniendo en cuenta metodologías emergentes en el relevamiento de necesidades. El ciclo 
formativo virtual será una capacidad instalada a seguir siendo utilizada en el futuro por la Cátedra 
UNESCO EPJA.
Outcome EN: Enabling Outcome 10 - Reinforced partnerships, outreach and advocacy in support of UNESCO’s action
Output EN: 10.PPF1 - Participation Programme management significantly improved allowing greater transparency, timely coordination among sectors and responsiveness, and an increase in the number of projects approved for gender equality and countries in need, particul

Project: Creación y Conformación del Comite Nacional del MOST Paraguay
Description:
El objetivo de este proyecto es la instalación del Comité Nacional del MOST en Paraguay.

A lo largo de los años, el Consejo Intergubernamental del Programa MOST ha subrayado el papel crucial Comités Nacionales y el valor de su contribución, destacando la importancia de mantenerlos en el contexto específico de cada país. Se alienta a los Estados Miembros de la UNESCO a establecer un comité nacional para alcanzar los objetivos del Programa MOST y, en particular, para desarrollar las capacidades nacionales en el área de las ciencias sociales.

El objetivo fundamental de un Comité Nacional MOST es el de fortalecer las capacidades nacionales de investigación en ciencias sociales (1), a fin de contribuir en el logro de las prioridades nacionales, y fomentar el vínculo entre la investigación social y los actores políticos que trabajan en el sector del desarrollo social.

Para cumplir con las formalidades necesarias, se inscribiría el Comité Nacional MOST Paraguay, en el Consejo Intergubernamental (CIG) del Programa de Gestión de las Transformaciones Sociales (MOST).

Los Comités Nacionales tienen la misión de lograr los objetivos del Programa MOST a nivel país. Persiguen los mismos objetivos, pero cada comité nacional tiene sus propias prioridades.

En el caso paraguayo, el desarrollo de las ciencias sociales, ha logrado avances en la última década como la creación de la Facultad de Ciencias Sociales en la Universidad Nacional de Asunción, el desarrollo de investigaciones y el apoyo a investigadores a través de programas del Consejo Nacional de Ciencias y Tecnología (CONACYT), la posibilidad de realizar cursos de postgrado en universidades extranjeras a través del Programa de Becas Carlos Antonio López (BECAL). La creación de universidades públicas y privadas en diferentes partes del país.

A pesar de estos avances todavía se necesita en el país un mayor impulso en el campo de la investigación, la difusión de los resultados y la utilización de los mismos en la formulación de las políticas públicas. Las políticas no siempre dialogan con las ciencias sociales y en ocasiones, a pesar de contar con datos e informes provenientes de investigaciones, estos no son aprovechados para el diseño y el mejoramiento de las políticas públicas, los planes y programas.

Además, Paraguay requiere mayor comunicación e intercambio con grupos académicos y e investigadores y centros académicos a nivel regional e internacional.

A partir de la instalación del Comité Nacional MOST, se elaborará una Agenda de Trabajo, con reuniones mensuales, observando las problemáticas sociales y coyunturales del país.

Project: Fossil and Stratigraphy Identification to study on Paleo-environment of Sount-west Cambodia
Description:
In the wake of an extraordinary milestone in Cambodia's scientific narrative, the discovery and publication of the country's inaugural dinosaur fossil. this proposal, titled Fossil and Stratigraphy Identification to study on Paleo-environment of Sount-west Cambodia takes center stage. The preliminary study conducted by the Department of Heritage Park, the General Department of the local Community,  Ministry of Environment of Cambodia, unveils a fascinating revelation. Between the years 2019 and 2023, 59 fossil-rich locations have been identified in Banteay Meanchey, Battambang, Koh Kong, Strung Treng, Ratanakiri, Prah Vihear, Posat, and Siem Reap Provinces, as reported in the department's preliminary findings).

These identified locations boast a diverse array of fossil types, ranging from marine fossils to petrified woods, enigmatic footprints etched in time, and dinosaur skeletons that have been published in MPDI as international articles of fossil studies. The significance of this discovery reverberates through Cambodia's natural landscape, urging us to embark on an ambitious journey of exploration and identification.

Despite the richness of these fossil sites in Koh Kong and Kompot provinces, the details surrounding the fossils, biostratigraphy, and paleontology remain largely undocumented. The preliminary study underscores a critical gap in our understanding, primarily attributed to a lack of expertise and specialized equipment. In response, this proposal seeks to address and bridge these gaps, propelling Cambodia into a new era of scientific exploration and documentation.

Through meticulous identification, study, and documentation of these fossils, we aim to elevate Cambodia's standing in the global paleontological community. Furthermore, by nominating key fossil-rich sites for consideration on the UNESCO Global Geopark and /or World Heritage List for  Natural Heritage, Cambodia aspires to not only safeguard its paleontological treasures but also to contribute invaluable insights to the broader understanding of Earth's ancient history.
Outcome EN: Enabling Outcome 10 - Reinforced partnerships, outreach and advocacy in support of UNESCO’s action

Project: Empowerment of women and girls in education: from rights to opportunities
Description:
The project "Empowerment of women and girls in education: from rights to opportunities" aims to promote the creation of an educational environment free from gender-based discrimination, fostering the development and self- realization of every girl and woman, regardless of gender.
Running from May 1st to December 31st, 2024 it seeks to provide a platform for discussing the challenges faced by women in the field of education and seeking solutions to address them
Expected results include improved knowledge and skills through conducting a two conferences and one workshop, the creation of a support network of educational professionals willing to collaborate and support each other in gender equality matters.
Project activities include two conferences addressing key practices and stereotypes in education and workshop on women's potential in education leadership, issuance of booklets on women's statistics in education, and the development of recommendations.

Project: "Empowering EMULI: Enhancing Mother Tongue-Based Multilingual Education in Timor-Leste through Knowledge Exchange and Collaboration"
Description: The Mother Tongue-Based Multilingual Education program (EMULI) in Timor-Leste aims to aid students in remote areas who do not speak the official languages by facilitating early learning in their mother tongue. Currently operating in 10 schools, the program has received 57 proposals from nearby schools for extension. Plans are underway to extend the program to more schools in 2024 and 2025, with a vision to expand further to different municipalities and language groups by 2026. To enhance implementation practices, the EMULI team proposes a study exchange to Cambodia in 2025, involving 10 individuals including EMULI team members, relevant Ministry of Education directors, and teachers. This exchange aims to learn best practices from a similar program and share insights through a follow-up seminar upon return.

Project: Develop and enhance digital literacy of science, math, and multimedia technology educators in Timor-Leste through capacity building and comparative study.
Description: Information, communication, and technology (ICT) have impacted the global society on how to network and impact human life. However, for developing countries like Timor-Leste, there needs to be a gap in how to introduce and integrate it into the education system. They considered the importance of ICT in the education system and realized that capacity building for their educators and the facilities that help support the implementation process is essential. Therefore, the Timor-Leste National Commission for UNESCO (TLNCU) would like to collaborate with the SEAMEO STEM-ED in Thailand to get capacity building related to digital literacy in science and math. After that, TLNCU collaborates with the teacher's training institute in Timor-Leste (INFORDEPE) to train high school science, math, and multimedia teachers on applying and integrating technology in the teaching process. To introduce, create, and develop didactic materials that integrate with technology, TLNCU expects that at the end of 2024, six trainers will train by SEAMEO STEMED-ED and be able to conduct teacher training for 78 science and math teachers around 13 municipalities. So that, at the end of 2025, they can apply it to the students in their schools.
Outcome EN: Enabling Outcome 10 - Reinforced partnerships, outreach and advocacy in support of UNESCO’s action

Project: Enhance the role of the National Institute of Science and Technology for the Research Ethics Committee in Timor-Leste through National training workshop and Climate change activities in the classroom and Knua Prátika (lab) at 9 municipalities.
Description:
-	The National Institute of Science and Technology (INCT) as a public institute, Independent and autonomous body. INCT is in the process of establishing its Research Ethics Committee. The aim for the INCT to submit this proposal is to organize training to enhance the capacity of the Research Committee and other higher institutions. INCT also requests for UNESCO to provide training related to Research Ethics for the committee members. 
-	The Timor-Leste National Commission for UNESCO and its science division called SESIM have organized a workshop on climate change at the national level for around 100 teachers and pre-service teachers in the last three years. We have developed a supplementary material for the climate change manual which the teachers could use and integrate with the science discipline.  The objective of submitting this proposal is to continue training more teachers at the laboratories (Knua Prátika-KP) recently established in 9 municipalities. There will be more local teachers participating in the training, including hundreds of students where the KPs are located.

Project: THE COLLECTION and DOCUMENTATION OF THE TRADITIONAL COSTUMES
Description:
Vanuatu is a vibrant and culturally diverse archipelago in terms of traditional costumes. Each village on the island of Vanuatu has its respective traditional costumes. The practice of making these traditional costumes is also very diverse depending on the villages and the islands. Moreover, with natural disasters, more particularly climate change, and the rise of the sea level, which is advancing at high speed, we must imperatively protect and safeguard our traditional knowledge as well as the plants for manufacturing these cultural artifacts. For this, an inventory should be urgently carried out to assess the situation concerning the plants from which plant is derived and lost. Emphasis should be placed on strategies to re-establish viable stocks of these plants on an island. Traditional exchanges of these costumes should be encouraged to perpetuate their know-how and their manufacture. Knowledge and oral knowledge of the traditional origins of these costumes should be urgently recorded by collecting from the men or women of each village.
The production and use of traditional costumes play an essential role in many rituals for the indigenous people of Vanuatu and should be revived and perpetuated. For this, a documentation and photography project should be undertaken for this purpose to document and archive all the stages of the production chain of these traditional costumes.
Outcome EN: Enabling Outcome 10 - Reinforced partnerships, outreach and advocacy in support of UNESCO’s action
Output EN: 10.PPF1 - Participation Programme management significantly improved allowing greater transparency, timely coordination among sectors and responsiveness, and an increase in the number of projects approved for gender equality and countries in need, particularly in Africa, developing countries, LDCs, and SIDS

Project: Workshop on Traditional House/Shelter (An exchange of traditional knowledge and skills and expertise)
Description: Vanuatu is a country that is prone to natural disasters. Tropical cyclones are a common occurrence in the country with a high prevalence (cyclone season) between the months of November in the previous year to April of the following year. Vanuatu’s cultures and traditions also revolve around these seasons, where crops are harvested and planted before and after the cyclone season, food is preserved for natural disasters, traditional structures are built that can withstand cyclone as seen when TC PAM struck in 2015, bringing with it a nationwide disaster especially in the two southern provinces of Shefa and Tafea. Although there were destruction to the gardens and structures, there were a significant amount of traditional structures that were used as evacuation centers and that withstood the destructive winds.

These classes at Niue High School promote national identity and pride, and seek to maintain the practices of weaving and craft making, passed on from our ancestors.  These are unique to Niue and intricate patterns that are traditional to Niue can be taught to the young women, who will then possess this knowledge and skills to pass on to their children.  This project focuses on female students and promotes craft as a focus in the school curriculum.

Project: Evaluating and Protecting Rarotonga's Key Ecosystems: Stream Health and the Preservation of the Last Fiddler Crab Habitats
Description:
Our initiative seeks to safeguard Rarotonga's ecosystems by conducting detailed stream
health assessments and conserving the last remaining fiddler crab habitat. Collaborating with
educational and environmental experts, we aim to establish a scientific baseline for ecological
integrity, inform targeted restoration, and engage youth through hands-on research and media.
The project intertwines community education with scientific rigor, utilizing SHMAK kits and
eDNA analysis. We require financial support for specialist expertise, educational materials, and
essential monitoring equipment to ensure the vitality of our streams, the survival of native
species, and the cultivation of environmental stewardship among the next generation.

Project: DEVELOPMENT OF A NATIONAL OPEN SCIENCE POLICY
Description:
Science, Technology, and Innovation (STI) are fundamental drivers of socio-economic advancement. As part of efforts to strengthen STI for national development, Government through the Ministry of Environment, Science, Technology and Innovation (MESTI), has recently reviewed its National STI Policy (2024-2030) in line with international trends and national priorities. Key to the policy is the adoption and promotion of Open Science Initiatives as an integral instrument for facilitating this transformative journey. 

To this end, the MESTI intends to initiate steps to develop an Open Science Policy in accordance with the 2021 UNESCO Recommendations on Open Science and Ghana’s STI4SDG Road Map.  MESTI seeks to achieve promotion of   a   common   understanding   of   Open   Science, developing an enabling policy environment for Open Science, investing in Open Science infrastructures and services, investing in human resources, education, digital literacy and capacity building for Open Science, fostering a culture of Open Science and aligning incentives for Open Science and promoting innovative approaches for Open Science at different stages of the scientific process.

Project: Effects of Electronic and medical waste on the Environment and Human Health: Engaging Schools and Communities to advocate for a more resilient ecosystem management
Description:
As we sail through the digital age, a new frontier has emerged in the realm of environmental protection—the online sphere. This vast interconnected landscape has become an essential catalyst in propelling discussions about various environmental issues, and medical waste management sits at the forefront of these conversations. According to statistics, of the total waste generated by health-care activities, 15% is considered hazardous material that may be infectious, toxic, or radioactive. Given the tremendous environmental repercussions associated with mishandling medical waste, it is imperative to address this issue head-on. In this project write-up, we will explore the intricate dynamics of medical waste, its environmental impact, the role of technology, existing challenges, and inspirational initiatives that provide a beacon of hope.
Medical waste is a huge environmental issue and according to records, every year, an estimated 16 billion injections are administered worldwide, but not all of the needles and syringes are properly disposed of afterward. Furthermore, the advent of the Covid pandemic has exacerbated the impact of medical waste. As demand for Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) – including gloves, masks, and gowns – grew worldwide in response to the Covid-19 outbreak in the last two years, medical waste disposal rates skyrocketed.

According to the World Health Organization (WHO), there are 8 types of medical waste: (Infectious waste, Pathological waste, Sharps waste, Chemical waste, Pharmaceutical waste, Cytotoxic waste, Radioactive waste, Non-hazardous or general waste).

The Covid-19 pandemic was not just a public health crisis, but an environmental crisis, too. An estimated 8 million metric tons of plastics already enter the ocean on an annual basis. According to a report by the World Health Organization, the medical waste accumulated during the pandemic increased plastic pollution in the oceans by 10 times.


On the other hand electrical and electronic devices generating e-waste are from IT and telecommunication equipment and consumer electrical/electronic products such as refrigerators, washing machines, computers and its accessories, brails, mobile phones and chargers, remotes, compact discs, headphones, batteries, LCD/Plasma TVs, i-pods, air conditioners, dryers, fridge, VCRs, stereos, copiers, fax machines, video games, presenters, music system and other household appliances etc. many of which contain toxic materials. It is estimated that about 50 million tonnes of e-waste is generated every year all over the world.

Consequently, as the Gambia is part of the global community, the management of hazardous electric/electronic and medical waste forms part of the major challenges the country is grappling with like many developing countries. Medical and e-waste are major problems posing very significant health and environmental hazards.
Outcome EN: Enabling Outcome 10 - Reinforced partnerships, outreach and advocacy in support of UNESCO’s action

Project: DEVELOPING EFFECTIVE CONTENT MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES AND ENHANCING STAFF CAPACITIES FOR OPTIMAL UTILIZATION OF MOES VIRTUAL INFORMATION CENTRE
Description:
The Ministry of Education and Sports (MoES) in Uganda has made significant strides in enhancing access to a diverse array of educational resources by establishing a digital/Virtual Information Centre (VIC) with support from UNESCO during the last Biennium, serving as a vital platform for disseminating crucial educational resources and information materials to both internal stakeholders within the MoES and the broader public.
Despite the extensive resources available within the centre, their utilization remains significantly below potential. This underutilization is primarily due to the absence of effective content management strategies and insufficient staff capacities among others.

Project: Capacity building and awareness creation of law enforcement officers on safety of Journalists, freedom of expression and the right to information in Uganda
Description:
Media Workers and Law enforcement agencies are often faced with many challenges to balance the rights to freedom of expression with the imperative to maintain impartiality and public order management. During turbulent times, law enforcement agencies have had to manage public safety issues around elections, natural disasters and public health emergencies, and facilitate respect for freedom of expression and the right to peaceful assembly. Political, social and economic circumstances have increasingly encouraged unrest among the public, placing officers in often difficult situations.
Against this backdrop, journalists and their freedom are increasingly threathened. A total of 1,088 journalsist have been killed for their work or while on job within the last 12 years. In the first half of 2022 alone, 45 media professionals have been killed. In response, government and law enforcement agencies have had to examine their ways of dealing with public order issues, working with journalists and communicating effectively with the public.
Despite the fact that media in Uganda has tremendously expanded and that Uganda’s 1995 constitution, the Press and Journalist Act, 1995 and other existing laws guarantee press freedom, so little has been done to promote media rights, safety and improvement of the working climate and conditions . The threats to free expression and access to information still remain in place. Together with the growing influence of business interests on the media, the threats continue to pose major challenges to the campaign for open dialogue, democratic rights and good governance in Uganda.  Concerns of this nature continue to keep human rights defenders in the country on their toes in search for ways to protect and promote open spaces where divergent ideas can flourish to foster democracy.
The Ugandan constitution and other existing laws guarantee press freedom, but the state actors usually ignores them at will. To compound the problem, the rate of impunity for crimes against journalists, media workers and social media producers remains high. Those involved in harassing media are never investigated and prosecuted. It is upon this background that we need as a country to promote press freedom at all level so that the gains realized is not washed away by the State actors.
Outcome EN: Enabling Outcome 10 - Reinforced partnerships, outreach and advocacy in support of UNESCO’s action

Project: PROMOTION OF ENVIRONMENTAL AND CLIMATE CHANGE EDUCATION IN THE PRIMARY TEACHERS TRAINING CURRICULUM
Description:
The project has been designed to promote integration of environmental education including climate change into the Primary Teachers Training Curriculum in Uganda.  
The approach to implementation of the project will include reviewing the existing Primary Teachers training curriculum for integration of environmental education. The review process will be participatory involving key actors in Teacher Education training and development. Workshops will be organized to assess teaching content including curriculum guides, leaners’ textbooks, examination papers and related materials among others. The review process will also help in determining tentative themes and some of the key actors to be engaged in subsequent stages.  This will be followed by participatory consultations where both physical and virtual media will be utilized and validation of the first report will be undertaken. The consultations and data collection are expected to target pre- service teachers’ learners in Primary Schools, District Education Officers, District Inspectors of Schools, Area Centre Coordinating Tutors, community members and environmental experts, educators including in service teachers, school administrators, curriculum specialists, examiners, education policy makers and related institutions among others. A series of engagements will be organized for data and information generation, validation, reporting and dissemination. The next stage will involve development of the Tutors guide or manual. The Tutors manual or resource book will be a practical support material for Tutors and preservice teachers in Primary Teacher Training Institutions. It will provide basic information on environmental education and Climate Change Mitigation actions in Primary Teachers Training Institutions A training of master trainers will be conducted who in turn will train selected tutors at regional levels to strengthen the capacity of Teacher Educators to promote A training of master trainers will be conducted who in turn will train selected tutors at regional levels to strengthen the capacity of Teacher educators to manage and promote environmental education and Climate Change Mitigation actions in Primary Teachers Training Institutions

Project: Projet d’éducation à la gestion durable des ressources en eau dans les établissements scolaires du Burkina Faso
Description:
Le projet d’éducation à la gestion durable des ressources dans les établissements scolaires du Burkina Faso véhicule des messages forts à travers ce constat : 

  L’eau est une grande préoccupation dans les pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest et sa bonne gestion est un devoir pour les gouvernants qui ont une obligation de moyens et pour chaque citoyen qui se doit d’adopter les bons comportements pour assurer la pérennité de cette ressource en eau. Bien plus que la vulnérabilité des pays de la zone face à une pluviométrie largement déficitaire et irrégulière, la prise de conscience des enjeux liés à l’eau a progressivement convergé vers un consensus pour une approche innovatrice de gestion des ressources en eau. La Gestion Intégrée des Ressources en Eau (GIRE) est ainsi apparue comme une des approches pour atteindre la bonne gouvernance de l’eau.

Project: Formation et accompagnement des femmes en situation de précarité dans  l’entrepreneuriat
Description:
L’autonomisation sociale et économique de la femme a toujours été considérée comme un préalable, notamment depuis la Conférence mondiale des femmes de Beijing (Chine). Elle est d’autant plus préoccupante de nos jours qu’il est impératif d’impulser une nouvelle dynamique si nous voulons atteindre les objectifs visés par les ODD4 et ODD5.
L’ONG « Femmes Engagées dans la Lutte contre la Pauvreté pour un Avenir Meilleur » (FELUPAM) œuvre pour offrir aux femmes et aux jeunes filles vivant en situation de précarité des formations en entreprenariat dans les domaines d’activités de leurs choix pour améliorer leur situation économique et sociale. 
Par le projet « Formation et Accompagnement des Femmes en situation de précarité dans l’entrepreneuriat », nous voulons former, sensibiliser et encourager les femmes gabonaises vivant en situation de précarité dans la création des Activités Génératrices de Revenus (AGR) en vue de leur  autonomisation. Les objectifs de ce projet visent à la réduction de la pauvreté, l'égalité des sexes et la croissance économique pour un développement durable. À travers des témoignages inspirants, le projet favorise l'entrepreneuriat féminin. Il aspire à la transformation des vies des femmes, de leurs progénitures, ainsi que des communautés et à promouvoir un développement inclusif.

Project: Promoting Female Sanitation and Hygiene Awareness Through Radio Programs
Description:
The project aims to promote female sanitation and hygiene awareness in high schools in Liberia through radio programs. This initiative recognizes the importance of promoting good hygiene practices among young girls to improve their overall health and well-being. By utilizing radio programs, the project intends to reach a wide audience of high school students and educate them on proper sanitation and hygiene practices specifically tailored to the needs of adolescent girls. The content of the radio programs will cover topics such as menstrual hygiene management, hand washing, access to clean water, and the importance of maintaining good personal hygiene. Through engaging and informative radio broadcasts, the project seeks to empower young girls with the knowledge and skills necessary to adopt healthy hygiene habits that will promote their well-being. 
The project aims to address the critical issue of female sanitation and hygiene awareness in Liberia through targeted radio programs. Liberia faces challenges in promoting proper hygiene practices among females, leading to health issues according to the World Health Organization (WHO), United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF), and Liberia Ministry of Education give their expertise on public health, child welfare, and educational policies related to sanitation, hygiene, and adolescent health in Liberia. This project seeks to leverage the influential medium of radio to disseminate essential information and foster behavioral change regarding female sanitation and hygiene. However, the lack of adequate information on sanitation and hygiene practices among females poses significant health risks among young females in Liberia. In response, this project proposes the development and implementation of radio programs aimed at raising awareness and promoting better sanitation and hygiene practices among high school female students in Liberia.
Outcome EN: Enabling Outcome 10 - Reinforced partnerships, outreach and advocacy in support of UNESCO’s action
Output EN: 10.PPF1 - Participation Programme management significantly improved allowing greater transparency, timely coordination among sectors and responsiveness, and an increase in the number of projects approved for gender equality and countries in need, particularly in Africa, developing countries, LDCs, and SIDS

Project: Radio Program on Early Childhood Development and Education in Liberia
Description:
Despite the recognized importance of early childhood development and education, there is a lack of widespread awareness and accessible information on best practices and resources for parents, caregivers, and communities in Liberia. Many families, especially in remote or rural areas, may not have access to formal early childhood education programs or may not be fully informed about the critical role they play in fostering their child’s cognitive, social, and emotional development. This gap in knowledge and resources poses a risk to the overall well-being and future success of Liberian children. Therefore, there is an urgent need for a targeted radio program that focuses on raising awareness, providing practical information, and promoting effective strategies for early childhood development and education, ensuring that all children in Liberia have the opportunity to thrive and reach their full potential.

The World Bank (2008), conducted research and provided reports on various aspects of education and development worldwide, offering insights into the importance of investing in early childhood education programs to widen the scope of understanding, especially in the rural areas of the country.

Project: TOT Workshops on the Preventions and Awareness of HIV/AIDS and Coronavirus for ASPnet Students and UNESCO Club Members
Description: Since there is no cure for either HIV/AIDS or coronavirus, preventive and awareness information should always be made available . Despite the information that there have been efforts to address HIV & AIDS and Coronavirus awareness in Liberia, there is a critical need for targeted interventions among ASPnet Students and UNESCO Club Members. These groups may lack comprehensive knowledge about preventive measures, transmission modes, and the importance of early detection for both HIV & AIDS and Coronavirus. Additionally, socio-cultural factors, stigma, and misinformation may contribute to the vulnerability of these populations. The overlapping risks and preventive strategies for HIV & AIDS and Coronavirus further emphasize the importance of a combined awareness workshop. Therefore, there is an urgent need to conduct workshops that specifically target ASPnet Students and UNESCO Club Members, providing them with accurate information, dispelling myths, and empowering them with the knowledge and skills necessary to protect themselves and their communities from both HIV & AIDS and Coronavirus. Moreover, HIV & AIDS and Coronavirus Prevention and Awareness Workshops for ASPnet Students and UNESCO Club Members in Liberia would typically outline the key issues that the workshop aims to address. In this case, the workshop would focus on highlighting the challenges and gaps in knowledge or awareness regarding HIV & AIDS and coronavirus among ASPnet students and UNESCO club members in Liberia. It would emphasize the importance of conducting a workshop to educate and raise awareness among these groups about prevention strategies, transmission modes, stigma reduction, and overall public health implications of these diseases.

Project: Promoting Reading Society in Liberia through National Book Fairs
Description: Despite the recognized benefits of fostering a culture of reading, Liberia faces challenges in promoting and sustaining a vibrant reading society. Factors such as limited access to diverse and affordable reading materials, low reading engagement levels, and a lack of community-based initiatives contribute to a diminished reading culture among the population. The absence of platforms like book fairs hinders the promotion of literacy, critical thinking, and intellectual growth. This gap not only affects individual development but also has broader implications for education, social cohesion, and cultural enrichment. Therefore, there is a pressing need to organize and promote book fairs as a means to encourage reading, improve access to a variety of literature, and cultivate a thriving reading society in Liberia. Moreover, Promoting Reading Society through Book Fairs in Liberia” revolves around the need to address the low literacy rates and lack of reading culture in Liberia. The objective is to promote a reading society by utilizing book fairs as a platform to engage the community, especially children and youth, in reading activities. This initiative aims to foster a culture of literacy, improve access to books, and encourage a love for reading among Liberians.

Project: Enhancing the 21st Century Comprehensive Sexuality Education (CSE) knowledge and support to 12 years Basic Education students: Pilot project in Kamonyi, Nyagatare, Rubavu and Gicumbi
Description:
Project’s main overall objective 
To provide 12YBE adolescents and young people in Rwanda with an opportunity to learn more about themselves, their interests, strengths, family and personal values and the factors that influence their sexuality.

Project’s specific objectives and planned activities to achieve expected results.
1.	To reach out to 12YBE adolescents and young people and equip them with skills that help them become competent enough in the context of sex and youth reproductive health without compromising culture and religion in Rwanda. This will be done through awareness raising in terms of trainings, massive campaigns and using mass media and organizing youth competitions in writing poems and music dance and drama and sports activities. The project will also distribute pads to 300 most vulnerable girls from poor families.
2.	To equip teachers with skills and approaches that will help them tackle Comprehensive Sexuality Education (CSE) in their class. This will help student develop positive attitudes towards Boy-Girl relations and the youth will be able to cope with sex related challenges and dilemma. The Knowledge will also result in prevention of early pregnancies that many girls in Eastern and southern province have been victims of. This will be done through training teachers on CSE in schools where they have not been trained, providing monitoring tools to trained teachers to capture progress and documenting gaps and lesson learnt for future improvement. Provide IEC’s and printed curriculums to teachers who may not have received them.
3.	To ensure adolescent students and young people can freely talk about issues that affect their Sexual Reproductive Health and adopt ways and manners that help make informed decisions concerning Boy-Girl relations and sexuality. Group discussions, hands-on activities and competitions will involve them in deepening the problem and by doing so they will develop the required competences in the field of Comprehensive Sexuality Education (CSE). Trainings in form of group discussions will be given to more than 13,500 individuals. Trainees will be both teachers (60) and 12YBE students from 30 secondary schools. RWACHI is expecting to use different activities to achieve the project’s goal.
Outcome EN: Enabling Outcome 10 - Reinforced partnerships, outreach and advocacy in support of UNESCO’s action

Project: IMPROVING THE  ENROLMENT  OF  FEMALE   SAHO  CHILDREN  THROUGH MOBILIZING THE SAHO COMMUNITY.
Description:
Southern Region is one of the densely populated regions of the country (Eritrea). Currently, it has about 800,000 population. It is one of the regions which share common boundary with Ethiopia. Large portion of the population in the region is affected by the 1998-2000 war of aggression, which was waged by the Tigray regime that resulted in the displacement of about 38 Schools with 22,202 students and 372 teachers.  The Tigray claimed some parts of these sub regions. School Facilities were pillaged by the Tigray military force.  
Although virtual demarcation had been given by the Hague, there had been skirmishes until 2022. As a result, there is feeling of trauma in the children.  There is a need of helping the people in general and the children in particular.
The economic activities of the region are predominantly agricultural with a very limited semi-pastoralism in the lowland areas.

Project: Start Them Right
Description:
The experiences children have in early childhood shape the brain and the child’s capacity to learn, get along with others and respond to daily stresses and challenges. Research has shown that readiness for primary school, which includes a child’s behaviour, readiness to learn, social and emotional skills, early literacy, and early numeracy are important skills to include on a school readiness tool as these skills had the most predictive validity for later school success. (Duncan,2007)
Early Intervention services are essential to ensure children's success. However, making a referral is only the first step. It's important to recognize that parents may face various obstacles, such as financial constraints, confusion, or discouragement, which may hinder them from following through with the process. Even if a referral is made, not all evaluations lead to services. Nonetheless, every child can benefit from some form of developmental support, and doctors' offices play a critical role in facilitating this. By making referrals and following up on them, we can ensure that children receive the services they need to thrive and reach their full potential. Science has proven how best to support children's development, but accessibility is key. Making referrals and following up on them is a crucial step toward ensuring that every child has access to these services. The ultimate goal of facilitating this kind of fair is to provide an opportunity for children to access services that can positively change the trajectory of their learning outcomes. The organization of the referral fair is grounded in the concept of that of a Health Fair but specifically designed for children who may have special needs. 
Therefore, The Early Childhood Commission, under the Theme Start Them Right, seeks to partner with child developmental specialists with the hopes of facilitating a diagnostic process. This will cater to the children showing delays in their learning or development. These children's records will be extracted from the from the ECC’s secondary-level screening tool data, Ages and Stages Questionnaire-Jamaica (ASQ-J). The Ages and Stages Questionnaire Jamaica is a development assessment tool that has been implemented in screening and referral pathways worldwide. It is designed to monitor a child’s developmental progress and identify children with potential developmental delays. It is used to further screen children who have been identified as “at risk” by the Jamaica School Readiness Assessment. Hence, the ASQ-J is a secondary screening tool which is used to pinpoint specific areas of risk so that interventions can be more targeted.
Outcome EN: Enabling Outcome 10 - Reinforced partnerships, outreach and advocacy in support of UNESCO’s action

Project: CHAMP (Child, Home and Mentorship Project)
Description:
Jamaica has made significant strides towards attaining the Sustainable Development Goals. In spite of these achievements, the country is still challenged by socio-economic development issues which range weak economic performance, poor student outcomes and high rates of violent crime. The COVID-19 pandemic has significantly impacted the academic performance of male students, introducing challenges such as disruptions to traditional learning environments and increased disparities in access to educational resources. Addressing these effects is crucial for ensuring equitable academic outcomes for male students during these unprecedented times.

The “Project” is a programme of mentorship and guidance, to support boys as they remain in school and work towards academic and professional goals.  The “Project” is designed to encourage Jamaican students, age 13-18 years old, and selected secondary school students to complete their education. The programme presents strategies which have the potential to make a difference to learning, motivation and engagement in schooling, and consequently to raise levels of academic achievement; personal and socio-economic development. 

To this end, the potential exists for the creation of employment and other opportunities to enhance the life chances of youth. This proposal outlines the CHAMP Project that will engage youth from low income households to develop critical thinking skills and offer them opportunities to promote sustainable development in Jamaica.
Outcome EN: Enabling Outcome 10 - Reinforced partnerships, outreach and advocacy in support of UNESCO’s action

Project: Brown Gold Operationalizing a social entrepreneurship model for upskilling and employing youth vulnerable to the effects of poverty in the community of Bruceville, Saint Lucia
Description: The premise for the proposed project is to show how sustainable agricultural systems can be a solution to important social challenges such as poverty alleviation (SDG 1) and access to decent work (SDG 8) in a practically relevant local scenario. The targeted community for the project is Bruceville, Saint Lucia which is noted as being vulnerable to crime, pollution, poverty and food and nutrition insecurity. The project aims to develop a sustainable community-based mechanism that contributes to poverty alleviation by upskilling youth (boys and girls) in organic waste utilization and conversion into commercial products using a social entrepreneurship model.
Outcome EN: Enabling Outcome 10 - Reinforced partnerships, outreach and advocacy in support of UNESCO’s action

Project: Prévention et lutte contre les feux de forêt dans le Parc national naturel Macaya (PNNM), zone sud-ouest
Description: Le Parc national naturel Macaya (PNNM) abrite sur plus de 13 000 ha un patrimoine naturel exceptionnel ayant le plus fort taux d’endémisme au mètre carré pour les Caraïbes. Cet espace est toutefois sous la menace d’incendies à chaque été, issue d’une combinaison de sécheresse et d’activités humaines. Le présent projet aborde cette problématique par une prévention ciblée avec les communautés proches du parc. Il vise à mettre en place un processus de mobilisation communautaire et d’accompagnement de la population sur la prévention et la gestion des feux de forêt.
Outcome EN: Enabling Outcome 10 - Reinforced partnerships, outreach and advocacy in support of UNESCO’s action
Output EN: 10.PPF1 - Participation Programme management significantly improved allowing greater transparency, timely coordination among sectors and responsiveness, and an increase in the number of projects approved for gender equality and countries in need, particularly in Africa, developing countries, LDCs, and SIDS

Project: Contribution à la sensibilisation sur l’eau, l’hygiène et l’assainissement dans les écoles
Description: En Haïti, de nombreuses écoles ne disposent pas d'un approvisionnement adéquat en eau potable ni d’installations sanitaires de base. Elles ne mettent non plus en œuvre des pratiques d'hygiène appropriées (UNICEF, 2017). De plus, des installations insalubres et non identifiées par genre ont été constatées dans certaines écoles ; ce qui pose des problèmes de sécurité pour les filles, constitue un facteur de propagation des maladies hydriques et peut entraîner absences ou abandons scolaires. Le présent projet entend contribuer à atténuer ces problèmes par la recherche, la formation et la sensibilisation dans les écoles.
Outcome EN: Enabling Outcome 10 - Reinforced partnerships, outreach and advocacy in support of UNESCO’s action
Output EN: 10.PPF1 - Participation Programme management significantly improved allowing greater transparency, timely coordination among sectors and responsiveness, and an increase in the number of projects approved for gender equality and countries in need, particularly in Africa, developing countries, LDCs, and SIDS

La meta general es el fortalecimiento de espacios comunitarios y no gubernamentales vinculados al trabajo con niños y niñas desde la primera infancia hasta el primer ciclo de la escuela primaria. El propósito perseguido se vincula a la creación y consolidación de equipos y formación de recursos humanos para acompañar las trayectorias de alfabetización mediante centros de promoción de la comprensión lectora, la producción escrita y la expresión oral en áreas no gubernamentales, comunitarias y organizaciones de la sociedad civil.

Project: Nuevos significados en wichí: patrimonio cultural inmaterial y mantenimiento lingüístico a través de un diccionario etnolingüístico monolingüe
Description: El proyecto se propone construir un diccionario etnolingüístico monolingüe con glosas en español a partir de elementos del patrimonio inmaterial wichí. Esperamos crear una herramienta que favorezca la transmisión de conocimientos a través del tiempo considerando también los cambios e innovaciones que hacen a la vitalidad de la lengua y cultura wichí. Se busca hacer un diccionario que permita acceder a otra cosmovisión, con el doble objetivo de contribuir al mantenimiento de la lengua y cultura wichí y de iniciar un camino hacia la interculturalidad crítica, desde una perspectiva decolonial.

Project: SVG - Response to students of the Grenadine Islands who must be relocated to mainland Saint Vincent to continue their schooling, as a result of Hurricane Beryl
Description: The Emergency Assistance Project provides a response to students of the Grenadine Islands, especially of Mayreau and Union Island who must be relocated to mainland Saint Vincent to continue their schooling, at least for a year, as a result of Hurricane Beryl of category 4 strength that struck the country on 1 July 2024, destroying the buildings of learning institutions throughout the Grenadine Islands, including the buildings of learning institutions in the Saint Vincent mainland. This project will allow for the purchase of standardized textbooks for affected students.

Project: El Pacífico al ritmo de la paz
Description: This project aims at creating spaces for dialogue and meaningful exchanges through the development of a regional artistic encounter, which will strengthen and showcase the process of composition and creation of original songs, highlighting the Colombian Pacific traditional rhythms, and exploring the region’s vast African heritage, as well as employing peace-building, reconciliation, diversity, genre and territorial reconnection approaches, ultimately becoming a tool to strengthen local identity and territorial appropriation. The project aims at developing a 3-day artistic residency and a public concert in Buenaventura with the participation of 110 children, teenagers and youngsters from Batuta’s from Buenaventura and Cali.

Project: Let’s Talk Youth Talk”:  to shape the life of others to achieve sustainable goals
Description:
The project aims to create a dedicated youth forum for young individuals to voice their opinions, concerns, and ideas. 
The forum will be guided by professionals in specific fields, fostering constructive dialogue and active engagement. 
The aim is to empower young people to contribute to decision-making processes and shape their surroundings. 
The forum will also encourage active participation, foster collaboration, enhance decision-making skills, amplify youth voices, and promote positive change. 
The proposed topics include developing leadership potential, dealing with emotions, speaking up, addressing violence, leveraging social media, promoting SDG strategies, and promoting self-defense. 
Both sessions will be competition sessions.

Project: Re-writing, Re-inhabiting The Island: National exhibition of self-histories of mobility and resistance of Afro-descendant women from Isla Trinitaria in Guayaquil, Ecuador.
Description: Re-Writing, Re-Inhabiting La Isla is proposed as a project of citizen, artistic, and cultural participation by Afro-descendant women of Isla Trinitaria in Guayaquil. Its purpose is to transform hegemonic narratives surrounding environmental racism, violence, and state exclusion of people of African descent. This transformation will be achieved through the creation and dissemination of Afro-centered artistic expressions, as well as the establishment of spaces for dialogue and exchange of knowledge. The project is rooted in the rich heritage of Afro-descendant women drawing upon their experiences and the collective memories and ancestral knowledge of Isla Trinitaria in the city of Guayaquil, Ecuador.

Project: Pilot Literacy Programme for Girls and Women in Jama, Province of Manabi
Description: This project expects to teach 40 women of different ages to read and write, using a methodology developed by Universidad Andina Simón Bolívar (UASB-E), which has been validated and applied in different educational settings. Two tutors from Jama will be trained on-site by an expert educator specialised in this methodology. In the mornings, the tutors will teach reading and writing to 20 adult women, and in the afternoons, to 20 girls and adolescents. During the training process, the literacy proposal, developed by Universidad Andina Simón Bolivar, will be systematised so it can be replicated in other communities in the country.

Project: STEAM Training, Support & Monitoring
Description:
The Division for Educational Innovation, within the Ministry of Education, Culture, Youth and Sport recognizes the importance of equipping educators with the skills to integrate STEAM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Arts, and Mathematics) into their lessons. Therefore, a comprehensive training program is currently in the development stage, scheduled to be implemented during the period September through November 2024. Funding has already been allocated for this training.

However, to ensure the effective implementation of the acquired skills, the Ministry also identifies the need for a post-training support and monitoring period for particularly educators in Secondary Special Needs Education. Thus, the Ministry is requesting financial assistance from UNESCO to cover the cost associated with this support phase for the period January through March 2025.

Project: The Perpetual Plastic Project
Description:
Environmental Protection In the Caribbean - Sint Maarten (EPIC) is currently in the process of initiating 'The Perpetual Plastic Project', a plastic recycling workspace project, of which it is still in the starting up phase. It will entail a few different phases, the one most of relevance here is phase 1: the education phase. Much of what EPIC is intending to achieve through this project, specifically this phase, matches with what UNESCO wishes to attain at many of the schools on Sint Maarten. A more cognizant youth practicing sustainability, thereby protecting the island and themselves and their futures. 

Phase 2 for this recycling initiative, focuses on the setting up a small-scale plastic recycling workplace for which specific machinery is necessary.  There are different types of machines for the different outputs envisioned. It mainly comes down to a shredder which shreds the plastics to small ‘malleable’ pieces, an injector which melts the pieces which can then be injected into small molds for smaller plastic items, an extruder which works similar to an injector but is there to create bigger items through bigger molds (think a keychain vs a beam for a bench), and a sheet press which melts down plastic pieces into big slabs (generally 1x1m – think: table tops etc.).
Outcome EN: Enabling Outcome 10 - Reinforced partnerships, outreach and advocacy in support of UNESCO’s action
Output EN: 10.PPF1 - Participation Programme management significantly improved allowing greater transparency, timely coordination among sectors and responsiveness, and an increase in the number of projects approved for gender equality and countries in need, particularly in Africa, developing countries, LDCs, and SIDS

Project: S.T.E.A.M. Education Policy for the British Virgin Islands
Description:
The Ministry of Education is actively engaged in the formulation of a comprehensive S.T.E.A.M. (Science, Technology, Engineering, Arts, and Mathematics) policy and advice concerning STEM education, delineating the strategic integration of these disciplines into the education curriculum for students across all grade levels and specifically highlighting girls and women in STEAM education.
This initiative is propelled by the recognition of the critical role S.T.E.A.M. plays in cultivating 21st-century skills among students and emphasizing the values to the fulfilment of UNESCO’s Strategy in STEM Education. In an era marked by rapid technological advancements and evolving global challenges, fostering competencies in science, technology, engineering, arts, and mathematics is paramount. These disciplines collectively empower students to think critically, solve complex problems, collaborate effectively, and innovate, thus equipping them with the essential skills needed to navigate and contribute to the challenges and opportunities of the contemporary world.

Se apunta a orientar a los actores educativos del Nivel Inicial sobre el manejo y ejercicio del concepto "sujetos plenos de derechos", además se pretende proveer herramientas para implementar estrategias con cuidadores y familias en la dimensión educativa y sistematizar las experiencias de la práctica en las diferentes comunidades educativas. La propuesta se realizará mediante talleres dirigidos a actores de la comunidad educativa del nivel inicial y para relevar la experiencia respecto al cumplimiento de los derechos en las familias con niños de nivel inicial.

(ENG) The aim is to guide the educational actors of the Initial Level on the management and exercise of the concept of "full subjects of rights", in addition to providing tools to implement strategies with caregivers and families in the educational dimension and systematize the experiences of the practice in the different educational communities. The proposal will be carried out through workshops aimed at actors of the educational community of the initial level and to survey the experience regarding the fulfillment of rights in families with children at the initial level.It aims to guide the educational actors of the Initial Level on the management and exercise of the concept "full subjects of rights", in addition it is intended to provide tools to implement strategies with caregivers and families in the educational dimension and to systematize the experiences of the practice in the different educational communities. Project: Masquerade lives on
Description: Masquerade , an African survival is seen erroneously as a stage item. It is a costumed dance street theatre performance but the tradition is defunct. Fragmented stragglers in costume are tragically incompetent and inadequate. They appear to know little about the raison d’être for this ancestral art form and are treated as nuisances . Former Minister of Culture, Dr. Anthony said many have ‘looked down’ on this art form, maybe because they were not aware of its rich historical and traditional value and importance to Guyanese heritage. If the culture is allowed to diminish, Guyanese will eventually lose their identity.

Project: Connecting Lives, Designing Futures – the journey of co- designing emerging communities and desirable futures in Aruba

This project is focused on the emergence of new communities through the application of
Futures -, Design - and System Thinking principles and by engaging our youth and lifelong
learners in co-designing possible futures related to education, preservation of cultural heritage,
work and sustainable development through intentional sustainability and personal innovation.
The project consists of the emergence of 3 laboratories:
o The Futures Lab (Collaboration, research, and co-design)
o The Playground (Capacity building and enhancement of creative confidence through
intentional serious play)
o The Multimedia Hub (Capacity building for media and computing literacy, cultural
preservation, digital library for forecasting)

Project: Projet Aladin- Sport contre la haine
Description:
Depuis plusieurs années, on observe une montée préoccupante de la haine dans la jeunesse, malheureusement trop souvent liée à des facteurs d'exclusion, ou à des soubresauts identitaires et religieux qui contribuent à noircir les relations entre les communautés. Ce projet est né du constat que le sport est un formidable vecteur d'intégration et de promotion du vivre ensemble. Le football est de loin le sport le plus populaire en Europe, avec plus de deux millions de joueurs en France et en Angleterre et sept millions en Allemagne. 
Le Projet Aladin et l'Institut des Accords d'Abraham d'Allemagne ont pris la décision de s'associer pour bâtir une coalition de clubs de footballs, en partenariat avec la FIFA, afin de sensibiliser des jeunes issus de quartiers défavorisés, aux ravages du racisme, de l'exclusion, de l'antisémitisme et plus globalement de la haine.
Outcome EN: Enabling Outcome 10 - Reinforced partnerships, outreach and advocacy in support of UNESCO’s action
Output EN: 10.PPF1 - Participation Programme management significantly improved allowing greater transparency, timely coordination among sectors and responsiveness, and an increase in the number of projects approved for gender equality and countries in need, particularly in Africa, developing countries, LDCs, and SIDS

Project: SCI-Beyond Borders: a Pan-African approach to international voluntary service
Description:
Beyond Borders seeks to promote regional integration, climate justice, and sustainable development in Africa. Through a Peace Caravan and community-rooted follow-up actions involving 9 voluntary organisations, the initiative aims to empower youth, enhance south-southcooperation, and challenge neocolonial motivations. Focused on eco-village development, climate change mitigation, and permaculture-based food security, the project includes hands-on activities, transformative workshops, and a documentary-video. By fostering collaboration and capacity building among voluntary organisations, the project strives to create a more interconnected, resilient network capable of 
 addressing regional challenges through a decolonial lens.

Project: URTI- Digitalisation de la Radio Publique en Afrique : enjeux, défis & feuille de route pour de rapides réalisations concrètes
Description:
La Radio en Afrique est toujours un média important pour l’information, la cohésion sociale, la diffusion culturelle, mais aussi, lors d’événements extrêmes - désastres naturels, mouvements sociaux, guerres - le seul contact avec les populations concernées. Et ce, dans les régions rurales, comme dans les centres urbains.

La révolution numérique touche aussi ce média si précieux. Mais tout à la transformation numérique de la télévision et des plateformes digitales, la radio est le parent pauvre, oublié des investisseurs. L’URTI propose une conférence qui mettra en lumière la numérisation de la radio numérique en Afrique et débouchera sur des propositions concrètes.

Project: FMOI-Formation à l’hydrologie de quatre techniciens(ne)s en vue de la réalisation de projets de deux ONG au Burkina Faso
Description:
Le projet s’inscrit dans le cadre de l’action coordonnée du groupe d’ONGs en relations officielles avec l’UNESCO soutenant les projets de formation en hydrologie en Afrique, et que le Programme de Participation a soutenus lors des deux premières sessions en 2016-2017 et en 2018-2019. 
La FMOI soutient deux projets de terrain au Burkina Faso, portés par les ONG APESI et APS, qui ont chacun présenté deux candidats au stage de technicien hydrologue : Mme Sabine Coulibaly Ouarme, M. Marc Ouedraogo (APESI), M. Uriel Ouedraogo, M. Franck Kaboré (APS).
APESI a pour projet dans le village de Tanghin Dassouri (Kadiogo) mettre en place des systèmes d'irrigation et de pompage solaire avec Formation des acteurs locaux. APS a pour projet la formation responsables et population de 8 communes rurales (350 000 hb) de Passoré Nord et Centre sur 100 forages et pompes

Project: World Ort-Phasing Forward: STEM Learning & Leadership in Coastal Ghana
Description:
Advancing four UNESCO priorities—education in Africa, gender equality, developing countries, and youth—World ORT aims to continue the iterative growth of a beloved STEM learning model that’s getting attention in coastal Ghana. Leveraging young Ghanaians’ sincere interest in digital technologies for learning, imagining, creating, sharing, and addressing matters of excitement/concern in their own communities, our participant-driven approach addresses many pressing issues of our time:
•	Education of the most vulnerable.
•	Access to information, data, science knowledge.
•	Community-driven grant-making and initiatives.
•	21st century skills digital literacies, collaborative agenda-setting and problem-solving, consideration/action around future challenges, etc.
•	Inclusion, equality, and equity in STEM
Outcome EN: Enabling Outcome 10 - Reinforced partnerships, outreach and advocacy in support of UNESCO’s action
Output EN: 10.PPF1 - Participation Programme management significantly improved allowing greater transparency, timely coordination among sectors and responsiveness, and an increase in the number of projects approved for gender equality and countries in need, particularly in Africa, developing countries, LDCs, and SIDS

Project: TAFISA-Womens Leadership in Sport for All Programme
Description: TAFISA will collaborate with local partner TIBU Africa to address gender equity in sports across Morocco and Northern Africa. Through workshops, mentorship, and networking, the project aims to empower women leaders, enhance gender equality in sports governance, and promote social inclusion. The initiative aligns with UN Sustainable Development Goals, focusing on training women in Sport for All leadership, fostering regional networks, and advocating for gender equity policies. By empowering local women, the project seeks to catalyse broader social change, promoting women's participation and leadership in sports across the region, with measurable impact and sustainable outcomes.
Outcome EN: Enabling Outcome 10 - Reinforced partnerships, outreach and advocacy in support of UNESCO’s action
